vi_translation: "This guy is just a friend." "I told you, we will talk about that later."
tr_translation: “This gentleman is a friend of mine. I had told you that we would discuss that matter later.”
es_translation: —He's just a friend. I already told you that we would talk about that another time.

en: “I beg your pardon,” said Mr. Wolfshiem, “I had a wrong man.”
vi: "Tôi xin lỗi anh, tôi nhận lầm người." Wolfsheim nói.
tr: “Affedersin, demek ben yanlış anlamışım.
es: —Le pido disculpas —dijo mister Wolfshiem—. Me he equivocado.
vi_translation: "I'm sorry, I mistook you for someone else." Wolfsheim said.
tr_translation: “Sorry, it seems I misunderstood.”
es_translation: —I apologize —said Mr. Wolfshiem—. I was mistaken.

en: A succulent hash arrived, and Mr. Wolfshiem, forgetting the more sentimental atmosphere of the old Metropole, began to eat with ferocious delicacy. His eyes, meanwhile, roved very slowly all around the room—he completed the arc by turning to inspect the people directly behind. I think that, except for my presence, he would have taken one short glance beneath our own table.
vi: Món thịt bằm ngon lành được dọn lên, Wolfsheim đã quên mất cái khung cảnh đầy đa cảm của quán cũ Metropole, bắt đầu ăn một cách lịch sự nhưng hùng hổ. Vừa ăn, cặp mắt của ông ta vừa đảo tròn chậm rãi nhìn chung quanh căn phòng, chấm dứt vòng nhìn của mình bằng cái xem xét những người đang ngồi ngay sau lưng. Tôi cho rằng, bởi vì có sự hiện diện của tôi, nếu không ông ta chắc cũng đã liếc nhìn luôn xuống dưới cả gầm bàn mình đang ngồi rồi
tr: Leziz yemeklerin gelmesiyle Bay Wolfsheim eski Metropole’in duygusal anılarını unutmuş, aceleyle yemeye koyulmuştu; arada bakışlarını etrafta gezdirmeyi de ihmal etmiyordu; son olarak arkasında oturanlara da dönüp göz ucuyla bakarak keşfini tamamladı. Muhtemelen ben olmasam eğilip masanın altına da bakacaktı.
es: Un suculento estofado llegó, y mister Wolfshiem, olvidando la atmósfera sentimental del viejo Metropole, empezó a comer con una delicadeza feroz. Sus ojos, entretanto, recorrieron muy despacio todo el local. Y, para completar el arco, se volvió a inspeccionar a las personas que tenía detrás. Creo que, si yo no hubiera estado presente, habría echado un vistazo debajo de la mesa.
vi_translation: The delicious minced meat dish was served, Wolfsheim had forgotten the sentimental atmosphere of the old Metropole restaurant, and began to eat politely but vigorously. While eating, his eyes slowly rolled around the room, ending his gaze by examining the people sitting right behind him. I suppose, because of my presence, otherwise he would have also glanced under the table he was sitting at.
tr_translation: With the arrival of the delicious dishes, Mr. Wolfsheim had forgotten the sentimental memories of the old Metropole and had hurriedly started eating; he did not neglect to glance around from time to time; finally, he completed his exploration by turning and looking sideways at those sitting behind him. He probably would have bent down to look under the table if I hadn't been there.
es_translation: A succulent stew arrived, and Mr. Wolfshiem, forgetting the sentimental atmosphere of the old Metropole, began to eat with a fierce delicacy. His eyes, meanwhile, slowly scanned the entire place. And, to complete the arc, he turned to inspect the people behind him. I believe that, if I hadn't been present, he would have taken a look under the table.

en: “Look here, old sport,” said Gatsby, leaning toward me, “I’m afraid I made you a little angry this morning in the car.”
vi: "Nghe đây, anh bạn già." Gatsby nó, nghiêng người về phía tôi. "Tôi ngại rằng tôi đã làm anh hơi giận sáng nay lúc ở trong xe."
tr: “Bu sabah arabada, ” dedi Gatsby bana doğru eğilerek, “seni kızdırmadım ya?
es: —Óyeme, compañero —dijo Gatsby, inclinándose hacia mí—. Me temo que esta mañana, en el coche, te he molestado.
vi_translation: "Listen here, old sport." Gatsby said, leaning towards me. "I'm afraid I made you a bit upset this morning while we were in the car."
tr_translation: “This morning in the car,” said Gatsby, leaning towards me, “I didn't upset you, did I?”
es_translation: —Listen, old sport —said Gatsby, leaning towards me—. I'm afraid I bothered you this morning in the car.

en: There was the smile again, but this time I held out against it.
vi: Lại nụ cười cũ nở ra, nhưng lần này tôi cưỡng lại được.
tr: Yine o gülümseme vardı yüzünde!
es: Allí estaba de nuevo la sonrisa, pero esta vez no cedí.
vi_translation: The old smile appeared again, but this time I resisted it.
tr_translation: There was that smile on his face again!
es_translation: There was the smile again, but this time I did not give in.

en: “I don’t like mysteries,” I answered, “and I don’t understand why you won’t come out frankly and tell me what you want. Why has it all got to come through Miss Baker?”
vi: "Tôi không thích bí ẩn." Tôi trả lời. "Và tôi không hiểu tại sao anh không thẳng thắn nói cho tôi biết anh muốn gì. Tại sao phải nhờ qua cô Baker?"
tr: Fakat bu defa direnmeye kararlıydım, “Açıkçası sırlar­dan hoşlanmam,” diye yanıtladım, “benden ne istediğini neden açıkça söylemediğini anlamış değilim, Bayan Baker’ı aracı olarak kullanmak neden?
es: —No me gustan los misterios —respondí—, y no entiendo por qué no me hablas con franqueza y me dices lo que quieres. ¿Por qué me lo tiene que decir miss Baker?
vi_translation: "I don't like mysteries." I replied. "And I don't understand why you can't just tell me directly what you want. Why go through Miss Baker?"
tr_translation: But this time I was determined to resist, "Frankly, I don't like secrets," I replied, "I don't understand why you don't tell me what you want directly, why use Miss Baker as an intermediary?"
es_translation: —I don't like mysteries —I replied—, and I don't understand why you don't speak to me frankly and tell me what you want. Why does Miss Baker have to tell me?

en: “Oh, it’s nothing underhand,” he assured me. “Miss Baker’s a great sportswoman, you know, and she’d never do anything that wasn’t all right.”
vi: "Ồ, không có gì là lét lút mờ ám cả." Gatsby trấn an tôi. "Cô Baker là một nhà thể thao danh tiếng, anh biết đó, cô ta sẽ không sẽ không làm bất cứ chuyện gì nếu như nó không đúng đắn."
tr: “Aman ha, bunun tekinsiz bir iş olduğunu düşünme sakın!” diyerek beni cesaretlendirmeye çalıştı. “Biliyorsun ki Baker büyük bir sporcudur, asla yanlış işlere kalkışmaz.
es: —No es nada turbio —me aseguró—. Miss Baker es una gran deportista, ya sabes, y jamás haría nada incorrecto.
vi_translation: "Oh, there's nothing clandestine or shady at all." Gatsby reassured me. "Miss Baker is a famous athlete, you know, she wouldn't do anything if it wasn't proper."
tr_translation: "Hey man, don't you dare think this is a shady business!" he tried to encourage me. "You know that Baker is a great athlete, he never gets involved in wrongdoings."
es_translation: —It's nothing shady —he assured me—. Miss Baker is a great athlete, you know, and she would never do anything wrong.

en: Suddenly he looked at his watch, jumped up, and hurried from the room, leaving me with Mr. Wolfshiem at the table.
vi: Đột nhiên Gatsby nhìn đồng hồ rồi đứng nhổm lên vội vã rời khỏi phòng, để lại tôi và Wolfsheim gồi lại trên bàn.
tr: Derken saatine baktı, sonra birden yerinden fırladı ve beni Bay Wolfsheim ile baş başa bırakarak çıkıp gitti.
es: De repente miró el reloj, se puso en pie de un salto y salió a toda prisa de la habitación, dejándome con mister Wolfshiem en la mesa.
vi_translation: Suddenly Gatsby looked at the clock and then stood up, hurriedly leaving the room, leaving me and Wolfsheim still at the table.
tr_translation: Then he looked at his watch, suddenly jumped up, and left, leaving me alone with Mr. Wolfsheim.
es_translation: Suddenly he looked at the clock, jumped to his feet, and rushed out of the room, leaving me with Mr. Wolfshiem at the table.

en: “He has to telephone,” said Mr. Wolfshiem, following him with his eyes. “Fine fellow, isn’t he? Handsome to look at and a perfect gentleman.”
vi: "Anh ta phải gọi điện thoại." Wolfsheim nói, mắt dõi nhìn theo Gatsby. "Anh ta là một thanh niên khá lắm, phải vậy không? Một con người vừa đẹp trai vài vừa hoàn toàn lịch thiệp."
tr: “Birine telefon etmesi gerekiyor,” dedi Wolfsheim onu gözleriyle izlerken, “Nasıl da hoş biri, değil mi? Çok yakışıklı, üstelik de tam bir beyefendi.
es: —Tiene que hablar por teléfono —dijo mister Wolfshiem, siguiéndolo con la mirada—. Un tipo estupendo, ¿verdad? Da gusto verlo y es un perfecto caballero.
vi_translation: "He has to make a phone call." Wolfsheim said, eyes following Gatsby. "He is quite a young man, isn't he? A man both handsome and entirely courteous."
tr_translation: “Someone needs to make a phone call,” said Wolfsheim as he watched him with his eyes, “Isn't he such a nice person? Very handsome, and a complete gentleman too.”
es_translation: —He has to make a phone call —said Mr. Wolfshiem, following him with his gaze—. A great guy, isn't he? It's a pleasure to see him and he is a perfect gentleman.

en: “Yes.”
vi: "Đúng vậy."
tr: “Evet.
es: —Sí.
vi_translation: "That's right."
tr_translation: “Yes.”
es_translation: —Yes.

en: “He’s an Oggsford man.”
vi: "Anh ta là dân Oggsford"
tr: “Evet.
es: —Estudió en Oggsford.
vi_translation: "He is from Oggsford"
tr_translation: “Yes.”
es_translation: —He studied at Oggsford.

en: “He went to Oggsford College in England. You know Oggsford College?”
vi: "Anh ta theo học Oggsford ở Anh Quốc. Anh có biết trường Oggsford không?"
tr: “Ya? “Evet, İngiltere’deki Ogsford Koleji’nden mezunmuş. Siz bilir misiniz Ogsford’u?
es: —Fue al Oggsford College, en Inglaterra. ¿Conoce el Oggsford College?
vi_translation: "He studied at Oggsford in England." "Do you know the school Oggsford?"
tr_translation: “Yes, he graduated from Ogsford College in England. Do you know Ogsford?”
es_translation: —He went to Oggsford College, in England. Do you know Oggsford College?

en: “I’ve heard of it.”
vi: "Tôi có nghe nói về trường này."
tr: “Duymuştum.
es: —Algo he oído.
vi_translation: "I have heard about this school."
tr_translation: “I had heard.”
es_translation: —I've heard something.

en: “It’s one of the most famous colleges in the world.”
vi: "Nó là một trong những trường đại học nổi tiếng nhất trên thế giới."
tr: “Dünyanın en ünlü okullarından biridir.
es: —Es uno de los más famosos colleges del mundo.
vi_translation: "It is one of the most famous universities in the world."
tr_translation: “It is one of the most famous schools in the world.”
es_translation: —It is one of the most famous colleges in the world.

en: “Have you known Gatsby for a long time?” I inquired.
vi: "Ông quen biết Gatsby lâu lắm rồi hả?" Tôi gạn hỏi.
tr: “Gatsby’i ne zamandır tanırsınız?” diye sordum.
es: —¿Hace mucho que conoce a Gatsby? —pregunté.
vi_translation: "Have you known Gatsby for a long time?" I probed.
tr_translation: “How long have you known Gatsby?” I asked.
es_translation: —Have you known Gatsby for long? —I asked.

en: “Several years,” he answered in a gratified way. “I made the pleasure of his acquaintance just after the war. But I knew I had discovered a man of fine breeding after I talked with him an hour. I said to myself: ‘There’s the kind of man you’d like to take home and introduce to your mother and sister.’ ” He paused. “I see you’re looking at my cuff buttons.”
vi: "Nhiều năm rồi." Wolfsheim trả lời một cách hài lòng. "Tôi vui mừng đã quen được anh ta, ngay sau chiến tranh. Chỉ sau khi nói chuyện với anh ta chừng một tiếng đồng hồ, tôi biết mình đã khám phá ra một thanh niên ưu tú. Tôi tự nói với mình: 'Đây là loại thanh niên ta muốn đưa về nhà giới thiệu cho mẹ và em gái. '" Wolfsheim ngừng một chút.
tr: “Uzun yıllardır,” dedi gururla, “kendisiyle savaştan hemen sonra tanışma şerefine nail oldum. Karşımdakinin bir asil olduğunu anlamam için bir saatlik sohbet yetmişti. Kendi kendime, ‘İşte bu evine davet ederek annen ve kız kardeşinle tanıştırabileceğin türden bir beyefendi’ demiştim.” Bir an duraksadıktan sonra, “Görüyorum ki kol düğmelerime bakıyorsunuz,” dedi.
es: —Varios años —contestó, complacido—. Tuve el placer de conocerlo recién acabada la guerra. Pero supe que había descubierto a un hombre de excelente crianza después de hablar con él una hora. Me dije: «Éste es el tipo de hombre al que llevarías encantado a casa y le presentarías a tu madre y a tu hermana» —hizo una pausa—. Veo que está mirando mis gemelos.
vi_translation: "Many years now." Wolfsheim replied contentedly. "I am glad to have known him, right after the war. Only after talking to him for about an hour, I knew I had discovered an outstanding young man. I told myself: 'This is the kind of young man I want to bring home to introduce to my mother and sister.'" Wolfsheim paused for a moment. "I noticed you were looking at my cufflinks."
tr_translation: “For many years,” he said proudly, “I had the honor of meeting him right after the war. An hour of conversation was enough for me to understand that the person in front of me was a nobleman. To myself, I said, ‘This is the kind of gentleman you can invite to your home and introduce to your mother and sister.’” After pausing for a moment, he said, “I see you are looking at my cufflinks.”
es_translation: —Several years —he replied, pleased—. I had the pleasure of meeting him just after the war ended. But I knew that I had discovered a man of excellent upbringing after talking to him for an hour. I said to myself: "This is the kind of man you would happily take home and introduce to your mother and sister" —he paused—. I see you are looking at my cufflinks.

en: I hadn’t been looking at them, but I did now. They were composed of oddly familiar pieces of ivory.
vi: "Tôi nhận ra anh đang nhìn nút cài tay áo của tôi." Thật ra tôi không hề nhìn, nhưng nghe ông ta nói thì bây giờ tôi quay nhìn thật. Chúng được làm từ những mảnh ngà voi hìng dáng không giống như thường thấy.
tr: Aslında bakmıyordum ancak bu sözün üzerine haliyle baktım, fildişine benziyorlardı ancak her nedense çok tanıdık gelmişlerdi.
es: Yo no estaba mirando los gemelos, pero los miré entonces. Estaban hechos con piezas de marfil extrañamente familiares.
vi_translation: In fact, I wasn't looking, but hearing him say that, I now turned to look. They were made from pieces of ivory in shapes not commonly seen.
tr_translation: Actually, I wasn't looking, but naturally, I looked after hearing those words; they resembled ivory, but for some reason, they seemed very familiar.
es_translation: I was not looking at the binoculars, but then I looked at them. They were made with strangely familiar pieces of ivory.

en: “Finest specimens of human molars,” he informed me.
vi: "Chúng là những miếng răng hàm đẹp nhất của con người." Ông ta cho tôi hay.
tr: “Bunlar insan dişlerinin mükemmel örnekleri,” diyerek beni bilgilendirdi.
es: —Los mejores ejemplares de molares humanos —me informó.
vi_translation: "They are the most beautiful molars of a human." He informed me.
tr_translation: “These are perfect examples of human teeth,” he informed me.
es_translation: —The finest specimens of human molars —he informed me. —Don't tell me!

en: “Well!” I inspected them. “That’s a very interesting idea.”
vi: "Chà!" Tôi xem xét. "Đây thật là một sáng kiến ngộ nghĩnh."
tr: “Çok ilginç,” diyerek daha yakından inceledim, “Fevkalade bir fikir.
es: —¡No me diga! —los examiné—. Es una idea muy interesante.
vi_translation: "Wow!" I observed. "This is really an amusing initiative."
tr_translation: “Very interesting,” I said, examining it more closely, “An extraordinary idea.”
es_translation: —I examined them—. It's a very interesting idea.

en: When the subject of this instinctive trust returned to the table and sat down Mr. Wolfshiem drank his coffee with a jerk and got to his feet.
vi: Khi nhân vật đáng tín cẩn đang được nói tới này quay trở về ngồi vào bàn, ông Wolfsheim thình lình uống cạn ly cà phê của mình rồi đứng lên.
tr: Bu büyük itimada ve övgüye layık görülmüş olan Gatsby masaya döner dönmez, Bay Wolfsheim kahvesini bir dikişte bitirip aceleyle ayağa kalktı.
es: Cuando el merecedor de aquella confianza instintiva volvió y se sentó a la mesa, mister Wolfshiem se bebió el café de un tirón y se levantó.
vi_translation: When this trustworthy character being talked about returned to sit at the table, Mr. Wolfsheim suddenly drank up his coffee and then stood up.
tr_translation: As soon as Gatsby, who had been deemed worthy of this great trust and praise, returned to the table, Mr. Wolfsheim finished his coffee in one gulp and hurriedly stood up.
es_translation: When the one deserving of that instinctive trust returned and sat at the table, Mr. Wolfshiem drank his coffee in one gulp and stood up.

en: “I have enjoyed my lunch,” he said, “and I’m going to run off from you two young men before I outstay my welcome.”
vi: "Bữa ăn trưa này ngon lắm." Ông ta nói. "Nhưng bây giờ tôi phải chia tay với các anh trước khi các anh cho tôi là quấy rầy."
tr: “Yemek bir harikaydı. Fakat kalıp da konukseverliğinizi kötü­ye kullanmak istemem, vakitlice kalkıp siz iki delikanlıyı baş başa bıraksam iyi olacak.
es: —Ha sido un placer comer con ustedes —dijo—, pero voy a dejarlos. Son jóvenes y no quiero que me consideren un pesado.
vi_translation: "This lunch is very delicious." He said. "But now I must part ways with you before you consider me a nuisance."
tr_translation: “The meal was wonderful. However, I don't want to overstay my welcome, so it would be best if I leave promptly and let you two young men have some time alone.”
es_translation: —It has been a pleasure eating with you —he said—, but I am going to leave you. You are young, and I don't want you to consider me a bore.

en: “Don’t hurry Meyer,” said Gatsby, without enthusiasm. Mr. Wolfshiem raised his hand in a sort of benediction.
vi: "Không có gì phải vội và Meyer." Gatsby nói nhưng không tỏ vẻ gì sốt sắng lắm. Ông Wolfsheim dơ cánh tay của mình lên chào như làm lễ.
tr: “Lüzum yoktu Meyer,” dedi Gatsby yarım ağızla, Bay Wolfsheim ise bizi kutsayamaya hazırlanıyormuşçasına elini kaldırarak,
es: —No tengas prisa, Meyer —dijo Gatsby, sin entusiasmo. Mister Wolfshiem levantó la mano en una especie de bendición.
vi_translation: "There's no need to hurry, Meyer." Gatsby said, but he didn't seem very eager. Mr. Wolfsheim raised his arm in a gesture of salute.
tr_translation: “There was no need, Meyer,” said Gatsby half-heartedly, while Mr. Wolfsheim raised his hand as if preparing to bless us,
es_translation: —Don't be in a hurry, Meyer —said Gatsby, without enthusiasm. Mister Wolfshiem raised his hand in a sort of blessing.

en: “You’re very polite, but I belong to another generation,” he announced solemnly. “You sit here and discuss your sports and your young ladies and your—” He supplied an imaginary noun with another wave of his hand. “As for me, I am fifty years old, and I won’t impose myself on you any longer.”
vi: "Anh thật là lịch sự, nhưng tôi thuộc về thế hệ khác." Ông ta tuyên bố một cách trang trọng. "Hai anh cứ ngồi ở đây mà bàn bạc chuyện thể thao, chuyện đàn và chuyện...." Ông ta thay danh từ cuối cùng đầy tưởng tượng của mình bằng một cái vẫy ta nữa. "Còn tôi, tôi đã năm mươi tuổi rồi, tôi không muốn làm phiền các anh lâu hơn."
tr: “Çok zarifsiniz ancak malum, kuşak farkı,” dedi ciddi bir tavırla, “Siz gençlerin baş başa konuşacak çok şeyiniz vardır; yaptığınız sporlar, görüştüğünüz hanımlar, sonra…” elini bir kez daha kaldırıp sallayarak meçhul bir imada bulunduktan sonra, “bense ellisine merdiven dayamış bir adamım, bizden geçti artık… Daha fazla zamanınızı almayayım.
es: —Eres muy amable, pero pertenezco a otra generación —anunció solemnemente—. Ustedes se quedan aquí y hablan de sus diversiones, de sus amigas, de sus… —un vago movimiento de la mano sustituyó a un nombre imaginario—. En lo que a mí concierne, tengo cincuenta años y no quiero seguir imponiéndoles mi presencia.
vi_translation: "You are very polite, but I belong to a different generation." He declared solemnly. "You two can sit here and discuss sports, music, and..." He replaced his last imaginative noun with another wave of his hand. "As for me, I am fifty years old, I don't want to bother you any longer."
tr_translation: “You are very kind, but you know, there is a generation gap,” he said with a serious demeanor, “You young people have a lot to talk about among yourselves; the sports you do, the ladies you meet, then…” after raising his hand and waving it once more in an ambiguous gesture, “as for me, I am a man nearing fifty, our time has passed…” I won't take up more of your time.”
es_translation: —You are very kind, but I belong to another generation —he announced solemnly—. You stay here and talk about your amusements, your friends, your… —a vague hand gesture replaced an imaginary name—. As for me, I am fifty years old and I do not want to keep imposing my presence on you.

en: As he shook hands and turned away his tragic nose was trembling. I wondered if I had said anything to offend him.
vi: Khi Wolfsheim bắt tay chào và quay mình bước đi, thì chiếc mũi thảm thương của ông rung rung. Tôi tự hỏi không biết mình có nói điều gì làm phật lòng ông ta hay không.
tr: Sonra ellerimizi sıktı, tam dönerken o tuhaf burnu titriyormuş gibi göründü gözüme; acaba kalbini kıracak bir şey mi söyledim, diye düşündüm.
es: Cuando nos dio la mano y se volvió, le temblaba la nariz trágica. Me pregunté si había dicho yo algo que pudiera ofenderlo.
vi_translation: When Wolfsheim shook hands in farewell and turned to leave, his pitiable nose quivered. I wondered if I had said something to offend him.
tr_translation: Then we shook hands, and just as he was turning away, his strange nose seemed to be twitching; I wondered if I had said something that hurt his feelings.
es_translation: When he shook our hand and turned away, his tragic nose was trembling. I wondered if I had said something that could have offended him.

en: “He becomes very sentimental sometimes,” explained Gatsby. “This is one of his sentimental days. He’s quite a character around New York—a denizen of Broadway.”
vi: "Đôi khi ông ta trở nên rất đa cảm." Gatsby giải thích. "Hôm nay là một trong những ngày đa cảm của ông ta. Ông ta thật là một nhân vật đặc biệt ở New York, một cư dân của Broadway."
tr: “Zaman zaman böyle duygusallaşır işte,” diyerek durumu izah etti Gatsby, “bu da anlaşılan öyle günlerinden biri. New York’ta tanınır ancak, aslında Broadway’dendir.
es: —A veces se pone muy sentimental —me explicó Gatsby—. Hoy tiene uno de sus días sentimentales. Es todo un personaje en Nueva York, vecino de Broadway.
vi_translation: "Sometimes he becomes very sentimental," Gatsby explained. "Today is one of his sentimental days. He is truly a special character in New York, a resident of Broadway."
tr_translation: "He gets sentimental from time to time," Gatsby explained, "and it seems today is one of those days. He is known in New York, but actually, he is from Broadway."
es_translation: —Sometimes he gets very sentimental —Gatsby explained to me—. Today is one of his sentimental days. He's quite a character in New York, a neighbor of Broadway.

en: “Who is he, anyhow, an actor?”
vi: "Ông ta là ai vậy, một kịch sĩ à
tr: “Ne iş yapıyor? Aktör mü yoksa?
es: —¿Es actor?
vi_translation: "Who is he, an actor?"
tr_translation: “What does he do? Is he an actor?”
es_translation: —Is he an actor?

en: “No.”
vi: "Không."
tr: “Ah, hayır.
es: —No.
vi_translation: "No."
tr_translation: “Ah, no.”
es_translation: —No.

en: “A dentist?”
vi: "Nha sĩ?"
tr: “Dişçi?
es: —¿Dentista?
vi_translation: "Dentist?"
tr_translation: “Dentist?”
es_translation: —Dentist?

en: “Meyer Wolfshiem? No, he’s a gambler.” Gatsby hesitated, then added, coolly: “He’s the man who fixed the World’s Series back in 1919.”
vi: "Myer Wolfsheim hả? Không phải, ông ta là dân cờ bạc." Gatsby ngập ngừng, sau đó lạnh lùng nói thêm. "Ông ta là người đã bố trí trước giải bóng chầy thế giới năm 1919."
tr: “Meyer mi? Daha neler! Kumarbazdır,” dedi ve bir anlık tereddüdün ardından serinkanlılıkla ekledi, “1919 Beysbol Turnuvası’na şike karıştıran odur.
es: —¿Meyer Wolfshiem? No, es jugador —Gatsby titubeó antes de añadir fríamente—. Es el hombre que amañó la serie final de las Grandes Ligas de béisbol en 1919.
vi_translation: "Myer Wolfsheim? No, he's a gambler." Gatsby hesitated, then added coldly. "He was the man who fixed the 1919 World Series."
tr_translation: “Is it Meyer? What nonsense! He's a gambler,” he said, and after a moment's hesitation, he calmly added, “He is the one who rigged the 1919 Baseball Tournament.”
es_translation: —Meyer Wolfshiem? No, he is a gambler —Gatsby hesitated before adding coldly—. He is the man who fixed the 1919 World Series.

en: “Fixed the World’s Series?” I repeated.
vi: "Bố trí trước giải bóng chày thế giới?" Tôi lập lại.
tr: “Turnuvaya şike mi karıştırdı?” diye tekrarladım.
es: —¿Amañó la serie final? —repetí.
vi_translation: "Arrangements before the World Baseball Classic?" I repeated.
tr_translation: “Did he rig the tournament?” I repeated.
es_translation: —Did you rig the final series? —I repeated.

en: The idea staggered me. I remembered, of course, that the World’s Series had been fixed in 1919, but if I had thought of it at all I would have thought of it as a thing that merely happened, the end of some inevitable chain. It never occurred to me that one man could start to play with the faith of fifty million people—with the single-mindedness of a burglar blowing a safe.
vi: Sự hiểu biết này làm tôi choáng váng. Đương nhiên tôi nhớ giải bóng chày thế giới năm 1919 đã bị bố trí trước nhưng nếu như tôi có thể nghĩ về nó thì cũng chỉ cho là một sự kiện tự nhiên xẩy ra, kết quả của một chuỗi những diễn biến thông thường. Trong đầu tôi chưa hề có tư tưởng một người đàn ông có thể đánh lừa lòng tin của năm mươi triệu người mà mục đích chỉ như một tên ăn trộm đi đục két sắt.
tr: Duyduğum karşısında şaşkındım. Elbette 1919 Turnuvası’ndaki şikeden haberdardım, ancak muhtemelen uzun bir zinci­rin halkası olduğunu sandığımdan, sadece oluvermiş, diyerek geçiştirmiş, çok da üstünde durmamıştım. Bu işin tek kişinin başının altından çıktığını, onun da bir kasa hırsızının dakikliği ve ustalığıyla, elli milyon insanı oyuna getirebileceği aklımın ucundan geçmezdi.
es: La idea me dejó estupefacto. Recordaba, por supuesto, que en 1919 amañaron el campeonato, pero, si hubiera pensado en el asunto, me habría parecido algo que pasó simplemente, el eslabón final de una cadena inevitable. No se me hubiera ocurrido nunca que un hombre pudiera jugar con la buena fe de cincuenta millones de personas con la determinación de un ladrón que revienta una caja fuerte.
vi_translation: This understanding stunned me. Of course, I remembered that the 1919 World Series had been fixed, but if I could think about it, I would only consider it a natural event, the result of a series of ordinary developments. In my mind, there had never been the idea that a man could deceive the trust of fifty million people with the same purpose as a thief cracking a safe.
tr_translation: I was astonished by what I heard. Of course, I was aware of the match-fixing in the 1919 Tournament, but since I probably thought it was just a link in a long chain, I dismissed it by saying it just happened and didn't dwell on it much. It never crossed my mind that this was orchestrated by a single person, who, with the precision and skill of a safecracker, could deceive fifty million people.
es_translation: The idea left me stunned. I remembered, of course, that in 1919 they rigged the championship, but if I had thought about it, it would have seemed like something that just happened, the final link in an inevitable chain. It would never have occurred to me that a man could play with the good faith of fifty million people with the determination of a thief cracking a safe.

en: “How did he happen to do that?” I asked after a minute.
vi: "Ông ta làm sao làm được như vậy?" Sau một lát, tôi hỏi.
tr: Biraz sonra, “Nasıl yapmış?” diye sordum.
es: —¿Cómo se le ocurrió hacer una cosa así? —pregunté.
vi_translation: "How could he do that?" After a moment, I asked.
tr_translation: A little later, I asked, "How did he do it?"
es_translation: —How did you come up with doing something like that? —I asked.

en: “He just saw the opportunity.”
vi: "Cơ hội đưa đẩy đến thì ông ta chụp."
tr: “Sadece fırsatı görüp, değerlendirmiş.
es: —Se le presentó la oportunidad.
vi_translation: "When the opportunity presents itself, he seizes it."
tr_translation: “He just saw the opportunity and took advantage of it.”
es_translation: —The opportunity presented itself.

en: “Why isn’t he in jail?”
vi: "Tại sao ông ta không bị tù?"
tr: “Peki neden içeride değil?
es: —¿Por qué no está en la cárcel?
vi_translation: "Why wasn't he imprisoned?"
tr_translation: “So why isn't it inside?”
es_translation: —Why isn't he in jail?

en: “They can’t get him, old sport. He’s a smart man.”
vi: "Họ không thể bắt ông ta, anh bạn già. Ông ta là một người thông minh."
tr: “Kanıtlayamıyorlar ki ahbap. Ne cin adamdır o!
es: —No lo pueden coger, compañero. Es listo.
vi_translation: "They cannot catch him, old friend. He is a clever man."
tr_translation: “They can't prove it, buddy. What a cunning man he is!”
es_translation: —They can't catch him, buddy. He's smart.

en: I insisted on paying the check. As the waiter brought my change I caught sight of Tom Buchanan across the crowded room.
vi: Tôi nhất định đòi trả tiền ăn. Khi người bồi bàn mang tiền thối lại, tôi nhận ra dáng của Tom Buchanan phía bên kia căn phòng đông người.
tr: Hesap için ısrar ettim; garsonun paramın üstünü ge­tirdiği esnada, kalabalık lokantanın diğer ucunda oturan Tom Buchanan’ı gördüm.
es: Insistí en pagar la cuenta. Cuando el camarero me dio el cambio, descubrí a Tom Buchanan al fondo del local abarrotado.
vi_translation: I was determined to pay for the meal. When the waiter brought the change back, I recognized the figure of Tom Buchanan on the other side of the crowded room.
tr_translation: I insisted on the bill; at the moment the waiter brought my change, I saw Tom Buchanan sitting at the other end of the crowded restaurant.
es_translation: I insisted on paying the bill. When the waiter gave me the change, I discovered Tom Buchanan at the back of the crowded place.

en: “Come along with me for a minute,” I said; “I’ve got to say hello to someone.”
vi: "Đi theo tôi tới đây một phút." Tôi nói.
tr: “Bana eşlik eder misin?” dedim Gatsby’e, “Biri­ne selam vermem gerek.
es: —Acompáñame un momento —dije—. Tengo que saludar a alguien.
vi_translation: "Follow me here for a minute." I said. "I have to go greet this person."
tr_translation: "Will you accompany me?" I said to Gatsby, "I need to greet someone."
es_translation: —Accompany me for a moment —I said—. I have to greet someone.

en: When he saw us Tom jumped up and took half a dozen steps in our direction.
vi: "Tôi phải đi đến chào người này." Ngay khi đó Tom nhận ra chúng tôi, anh ta đứng ngay lên đi năm sáu bước về phía chúng tôi.
tr: O esnada Tom bizi gördü ve yanımıza gelmek için birkaç adım attı.
es: Tom nos vio, se levantó y dio unos pasos hacia nosotros.
vi_translation: Just then, Tom recognized us, he immediately stood up and took five or six steps towards us.
tr_translation: At that moment, Tom saw us and took a few steps to come towards us.
es_translation: Tom saw us, stood up, and took a few steps towards us.

en: “Where’ve you been?” he demanded eagerly. “Daisy’s furious because you haven’t called up.”
vi: "Độ này anh đi đâu?" Tom hỏi một cách hăm hở. "Daisy đang giận bởi vì anh lâu nay không gọi điện thoại."
tr: “Nerelerdesin sen?” diye çıkıştı, “Daisy uğramıyor oluşuna çok kızıyor, haberin olsun.
es: —¿Dónde te has metido? —preguntó con calor—. Daisy está furiosa porque no nos has llamado.
vi_translation: "Where have you been lately?" Tom asked eagerly. "Daisy is upset because you haven't called in a long time."
tr_translation: "Where have you been?" he snapped, "Daisy is very upset that you haven't been visiting, just so you know."
es_translation: —Where have you been? —he asked warmly—. Daisy is furious because you haven't called us.

en: “This is Mr. Gatsby, Mr. Buchanan.”
vi: "Tôi giới thiệu, đây là anh Gatsby và đây là anh Buchanan."
tr: “Bu Bay Gatsby, bu da Bay Buchanan,” diyerek tanıştırdım.
es: —Le presento a mister Gatsby, mister Buchanan.
vi_translation: "I introduce, this is Mr. Gatsby and this is Mr. Buchanan."
tr_translation: “This is Mr. Gatsby, and this is Mr. Buchanan,” I introduced them.
es_translation: —I present to you Mr. Gatsby, Mr. Buchanan.

en: They shook hands briefly, and a strained, unfamiliar look of embarrassment came over Gatsby’s face.
vi: Hai người họ bắt tay nhau ngắn gọn, gượng ép, một nét ngượng ngùng xuất hiện trên khuôn mặt Gatsby.
tr: Onlar el sıkışırken; Gatsby’nin yüzünde, daha önce hiç görmediğim bir utanç ifadesi fark etmiştim.
es: Se estrecharon la mano brevemente, y la cara de Gatsby adoptó una expresión de incomodidad y tensión que yo no le conocía.
vi_translation: The two of them shook hands briefly, awkwardly, an embarrassed look appearing on Gatsby's face.
tr_translation: As they shook hands; I had noticed an expression of shame on Gatsby's face that I had never seen before.
es_translation: They shook hands briefly, and Gatsby's face took on an expression of discomfort and tension that I had not seen before.

en: “How’ve you been, anyhow?” demanded Tom of me. “How’d you happen to come up this far to eat?”
vi: "Anh độ này ra sao?" Tom hỏi tôi. "Chuyện gì khiến anh đến mãi tận nơi này ăn vậy?"
tr: “Nasılsın bakalım?” diye sordu Tom, “Bunca yolu sırf yemek için gelmedin ya?
es: —¿Dónde te has metido? —insistió Tom—. ¿Cómo se te ha ocurrido venir a comer tan lejos?
vi_translation: "How have you been lately?" Tom asked me. "What brings you all the way here to eat?"
tr_translation: "How are you?" asked Tom, "You didn't come all this way just for the food, did you?"
es_translation: —Where have you been? —Tom insisted—. What made you think of coming to eat so far away?

en: “I’ve been having lunch with Mr. Gatsby.”
vi: "Tôi đi ăn trưa với anh Gatsby."
tr: “Bay Gatsby ile birlikteyim” diyerek döndüm, ancak Gatsby ortadan kaybolmuştu.
es: —He venido a comer con mister Gatsby.
vi_translation: "I went to have lunch with Mr. Gatsby."
tr_translation: “I am with Mr. Gatsby,” I said, turning around, but Gatsby had disappeared.
es_translation: —I have come to dine with Mr. Gatsby.

en: I turned toward Mr. Gatsby, but he was no longer there.
vi: Tôi quay sang Gatsby nhưng anh ta không còn đứng ở đó nữa.
tr: “Bay Gatsby ile birlikteyim” diyerek döndüm, ancak Gatsby ortadan kaybolmuştu.
es: Me volví hacia Gatsby, pero ya no estaba.
vi_translation: I turned to Gatsby but he was no longer standing there.
tr_translation: “I am with Mr. Gatsby,” I said, turning around, but Gatsby had disappeared.
es_translation: I turned toward Gatsby, but he was no longer there.

en: (said Jordan Baker that afternoon, sitting up very straight on a straight chair in the tea-garden at the Plaza Hotel)
vi: (Vào buổi chiều hôm đó, ngồi rất thằng người lên một chiếc ghế thẳng lưng trong khu vườn dành cho uống trà ở khách sạn Plaza, Jordan bắt đầu kể chuyện).
tr: “1917 yılı, bir ekim sabahıydı – (diye başlamıştı söze Jordan Baker, aynı günün öğleden sonrasında, Plaza Otel’in çay bahçesindeki dik sandalyelerden birinde dimdik otururken) – biraz kaldırımın, biraz çimenlerin üzerinden yürüyerek bir yerlere gidiyordum.
es: Un día de octubre de 1917… (dijo Jordan Baker aquella tarde, sentada muy derecha en una silla del café al aire libre del Hotel Plaza)… iba dando un paseo, por la acera y por el césped.
vi_translation: (That afternoon, sitting very upright on a straight-backed chair in the tea garden of the Plaza Hotel, Jordan began to tell the story).
tr_translation: "It was the year 1917, an October morning – (Jordan Baker had started to speak, sitting upright in one of the stiff chairs in the tea garden of the Plaza Hotel that same afternoon) – I was walking somewhere, partly on the sidewalk, partly on the grass.
es_translation: One day in October of 1917... (said Jordan Baker that afternoon, sitting very straight in a chair at the outdoor café of the Plaza Hotel)...

en: —I was walking along from one place to another, half on the sidewalks and half on the lawns. I was happier on the lawns because I had on shoes from England with rubber knobs on the soles that bit into the soft ground. I had on a new plaid skirt also that blew a little in the wind, and whenever this happened the red, white, and blue banners in front of all the houses stretched out stiff and said tut-tut-tut-tut, in a disapproving way.
vi: "Em đang đi bộ lăng quăng từ chỗ này tới chỗ kia, lúc thì ở trên hè đường, lúc thì ở trên những bãi cỏ. Em thích đi trên cỏ hơn, bởi vì em đang mang đôi giầy mua từ Anh Quốc có đế bằng cao su rất dễ bám vào đất mềm. Lúc đó em mặc chiếc váy sọc ca rô hơi bị gió thổi tung lên một tý. Mỗi khi như vậy thì những lá cờ mang màu đỏ, trắng, xanh trước cửa các ngôi nhà lại bay thẳng ra kêu lên những tiếnh "tut tut tut tut" một cách không tán thành.
tr: “1917 yılı, bir ekim sabahıydı – (diye başlamıştı söze Jordan Baker, aynı günün öğleden sonrasında, Plaza Otel’in çay bahçesindeki dik sandalyelerden birinde dimdik otururken) – biraz kaldırımın, biraz çimenlerin üzerinden yürüyerek bir yerlere gidiyordum. Doğrusu ayağımdaki İngiliz ayakkabıların kauçuk tabanlarının yumuşak toprağa gömülüşünden hoşlandığımdan, daha çok çimenlerden yürüyordum. Pilili eteğim ne zaman rüzgarda hava­lanacak gibi olsa, evlerin ön cephesine asılmış olan kırmızılı, mavi­li, beyazlı bayraklar da yükseliyor, benimle dalga geçercesine pat-pat- pat sesleriyle dalgalanıyordu.
es: Un día de octubre de 1917… (dijo Jordan Baker aquella tarde, sentada muy derecha en una silla del café al aire libre del Hotel Plaza)… iba dando un paseo, por la acera y por el césped. Me gustaba más el césped porque tenía unos zapatos ingleses con tacos de goma en las suelas que se hundían en la tierra blanda. Y tenía una falda escocesa nueva que se levantaba un poco al viento a la vez que en todas las casas se tensaban las banderas rojas, blancas y azules y decían tut-tut-tut-tut con tono de desaprobación.
vi_translation: "I was wandering around from place to place, sometimes on the sidewalk, sometimes on the grassy areas. I preferred walking on the grass because I was wearing shoes bought from England with rubber soles that easily gripped the soft ground. At that time, I was wearing a plaid skirt that was slightly lifted by the wind. Whenever that happened, the red, white, and blue flags in front of the houses would fly straight out and make a disapproving "tut tut tut tut" sound.
tr_translation: "It was the year 1917, an October morning – (Jordan Baker had started to speak, sitting upright in one of the stiff chairs in the tea garden of the Plaza Hotel that same afternoon) – I was walking somewhere, partly on the sidewalk, partly on the grass. In truth, I was walking more on the grass because I liked how the rubber soles of my English shoes sank into the soft ground. Whenever my pleated skirt seemed about to flutter in the wind, the red, blue, and white flags hanging on the front facades of the houses would also rise, flapping with a pat-pat-pat sound as if mocking me.
es_translation: I was taking a walk, on the sidewalk and on the grass. I liked the grass more because I had some English shoes with rubber studs on the soles that sank into the soft ground. And I had a new Scottish skirt that lifted a bit in the wind while in all the houses the red, white, and blue flags were stretched out and went tut-tut-tut-tut in a tone of disapproval.

en: The largest of the banners and the largest of the lawns belonged to Daisy Fay’s house. She was just eighteen, two years older than me, and by far the most popular of all the young girls in Louisville. She dressed in white, and had a little white roadster, and all day long the telephone rang in her house and excited young officers from Camp Taylor demanded the privilege of monopolizing her that night. “Anyways, for an hour!”
vi: Lá cờ lớn nhất và bãi có lớn nhất là thuộc về nhà của Daisy Fay. Lúc đó chị Daisy mới mười tám tuổi, lớn hơn em hai tuổi và là người nổi tiếng nhất trong đám những thiếu nữ ở Louisville. Chị ấy lúc nào cũng mặc màu trắng và đi chiếc xe mui trần hai chỗ cũng màu trắng. Cả ngày điện thoại trong nhà chị không lúc nào ngừng reo, do những sĩ quan hồ hởi từ trại quân đội Taylor gọi tới xin được đặc ân độc chiếm chị Daisy tối đó. "Cho dù chỉ là một giờ."
tr: “Hem bayrakların hem de bahçelerin en büyüğü, Daisy Fay’in evinine aitti. Benden iki yaş bü­yüktür, yani o zaman on sekizindeydi. Louisville’in en gözde kızıydı. Daima beyazlar içindeydi, hatta bir de beyaz, üstü açık arabası vardı. Her gün, durmaksızın evlerindeki telefon çalar, kent civarındaki kampta eğitimde olan genç subaylar, ondan bir randevu koparmak için birbirleriyle yarışırdı; aslında bir saatliğine bu­luşmaya bile razıydılar.
es: La bandera más grande y el césped más grande eran los de la casa de Daisy Fay. Daisy acababa de cumplir dieciocho años, dos más que yo, y era, de lejos, la chica más solicitada de Louisville. Vestía de blanco, tenía un pequeño descapotable, y el teléfono no dejaba de sonar en su casa: los jóvenes oficiales de Camp Taylor[12] exigían con emoción el privilegio de monopolizar a Daisy aquella noche. «¡Una hora por lo menos!»
vi_translation: The largest flag and the largest lawn belonged to Daisy Fay's house. At that time, Daisy was only eighteen years old, two years older than you, and was the most famous among the young ladies in Louisville. She always wore white and drove a white two-seater convertible. All day long, the phone in her house never stopped ringing, as eager officers from the Taylor military camp called to request the privilege of having Daisy to themselves that evening. "Even if it's just for an hour."
tr_translation: “Both the largest flags and the largest gardens belonged to Daisy Fay's house. She is two years older than me, so she was eighteen at the time. She was the most popular girl in Louisville. She was always dressed in white, and she even had a white, open-top car. Every day, their phone at home would ring incessantly, with young officers in training at the nearby camp competing with each other to get a date with her; in fact, they were even willing to settle for a meeting of just one hour.
es_translation: The largest flag and the largest lawn belonged to Daisy Fay's house. Daisy had just turned eighteen, two years older than me, and was by far the most sought-after girl in Louisville. She dressed in white, had a small convertible, and the phone never stopped ringing at her house: the young officers from Camp Taylor[12] eagerly demanded the privilege of monopolizing Daisy that night. "At least an hour!"

en: When I came opposite her house that morning her white roadster was beside the kerb, and she was sitting in it with a lieutenant I had never seen before. They were so engrossed in each other that she didn’t see me until I was five feet away.
vi: Sáng đó khi em đi ngang qua nhà chị Daisy, chiếc xe mui trần màu trắng của chị đang đậu sát hè đường, chị đang ngồi trong xe với một trung úy mà em chưa từng gặp trước kia. Hai người họ đang chú tâm vào nhau quá đến quá nỗi không nhìn thấy em cho tớ i khi em chỉ còn cách họ năm bước.
tr: “O sabah evinin önünden geçerken, beyaz ara­basının kaldırımın yanında park halinde olduğunu gördüm. Daisy de içinde, ilk kez o gün gördüğüm bir teğmenle beraber oturu­yordu. Birbirine öyle dalıp gitmişlerdi ki, aramızda iki adım kalana kadar Daisy yaklaştığımı farkına varmamıştı.
es: Cuando llegué a la altura de su casa aquella mañana el descapotable blanco estaba junto a la acera, y ella estaba sentada al volante con un teniente al que yo no había visto antes. Estaban tan absortos el uno en el otro que Daisy no me vio hasta que me tuvo a metro y medio de distancia.
vi_translation: That morning when I passed by Daisy's house, her white convertible was parked close to the sidewalk, and she was sitting in the car with a lieutenant I had never seen before. The two of them were so engrossed in each other that they didn't see me at all. when I was only five steps away from them.
tr_translation: “That morning, while passing by her house, I saw her white car parked by the curb. Daisy was inside, sitting with a lieutenant I saw for the first time that day. They were so engrossed in each other that Daisy didn't notice my approach until I was just two steps away.
es_translation: When I reached the height of her house that morning, the white convertible was next to the curb, and she was sitting at the wheel with a lieutenant whom I had not seen before. They were so absorbed in each other that Daisy did not see me until I was a meter and a half away.

en: “Hello, Jordan,” she called unexpectedly. “Please come here.”
vi: "Chào Jordan." Chị ấy đột ngột gọi em. "Đến đây đi."
tr: “Birden, ‘Ah, Merhaba Jordan’ diye seslendiğini duydum, açıkçası bunu hiç beklemiyordum, ‘Gelsene!
es: —Hola, Jordan —gritó inesperadamente—. Ven.
vi_translation: "Hello Jordan." She suddenly called me. "Come here."
tr_translation: “Suddenly, I heard him call out, 'Oh, Hello Jordan,' to be honest, I wasn't expecting that at all, 'Come here!'
es_translation: —Hello, Jordan —he shouted unexpectedly—. Come.

en: I was flattered that she wanted to speak to me, because of all the older girls I admired her most. She asked me if I was going to the Red Cross to make bandages. I was. Well, then, would I tell them that she couldn’t come that day? The officer looked at Daisy while she was speaking, in a way that every young girl wants to be looked at sometime, and because it seemed romantic to me I have remembered the incident ever since. His name was Jay Gatsby, and I didn’t lay eyes on him again for over four years—even after I’d met him on Long Island I didn’t realize it was the same man.
vi: Em cảm thấy hãnh diện vì chị ấy muốn nói chuyện với em, trong số những chị lớn hơn, em ngưỡng mộ chị ấy nhất. Chị ấy hỏi em nếu em có đi đến hội chữ thập đỏ để băng bó. Lúc đó em đang đi thật. Chị ấy nhờ em nhắn hộ với họ là hôm đó chị không thể đến được. Trong lúc chị Daisy nói chuyện, người sĩ quan cứ nhìn chị bằng cái nhìn mà tất cả mọi thiếu nữ trẻ đều muốn mình được nhìn như vậy. Cảnh tượng đó trông thật là tình tứ lãng mạn, nó khiến em nhỡ mãi. Tên của anh ta là Jay Gatsby, sau lần đó khoảng bốn năm em không còn gặp lại anh ta nữa cho mãi cho đến khi em gặp lại anh ta ở Long Island em cũng chưa nhận ra hai người họ là một.
tr: “Benimle konuşmak istemesi, beni onurlandırmıştı; zaten benden büyük olan kızlardan en çok ona hayrandım. ‘Kızıl Haç’a, sargı bezi paketlemeye mi gidiyorsun,’ diye sordu. Onayladım. O gün kendisinin gelemeyeceğini iletmemi istemişti. O benimle konuşurken, yanındaki teğmen onun yüzüne öyle bir hayranlıkla bakıyordu ki, her genç kız hiç yoktan ara sıra kendisine böyle bakılmasını isterdi. Bakışları öylesine romantikti ki, o sahneyi hiç unutmadım. O teğmenin adı Jay Gatsby idi. Sonraki dört yıl, onu bir daha hiç görmedim. Hatta dört yılın sonunda, Long Island’da tanıştırıldığımızda onun o teğmen olduğunu bile anlayamadım.
es: Me halagó que quisiera hablar conmigo, porque de todas las chicas mayores era la que yo más admiraba. Me preguntó si iba a la Cruz Roja a hacer paquetes de vendas. Sí, iba a la Cruz Roja. Bueno, ¿me importaría avisar de que ella no podía ir ese día? El oficial miraba a Daisy mientras hablaba, de una manera que cualquier chica desearía que la miraran alguna vez, y me pareció tan romántico aquel momento que no lo he olvidado. El oficial se llamaba Jay Gatsby, y no volví a ponerle los ojos encima hasta cuatro años después. Incluso cuando me lo encontré de nuevo, en Long Island, no me di cuenta de que se trataba del mismo hombre.
vi_translation: I feel proud because she wants to talk to me; among the older sisters, I admire her the most. She asked me if I went to the Red Cross to get bandaged. At that time, I was really going. She asked me to tell them that she couldn't come that day. While Daisy was talking, the officer kept looking at her with a gaze that every young girl wishes to be looked at with. That scene looked so romantic and affectionate, it made me remember it forever. His name was Jay Gatsby; after that time, I didn't see him again for about four years until I met him again in Long Island, and I still didn't realize they were the same person.
tr_translation: “The fact that she wanted to talk to me had honored me; after all, among the older girls, she was the one I admired the most. ‘Are you going to the Red Cross to pack bandages?’ she asked. I nodded. She had asked me to convey that she wouldn't be able to come that day. While she was talking to me, the lieutenant next to her was looking at her with such admiration that every young girl would want to be looked at like that at least occasionally. His gaze was so romantic that I never forgot that scene. That lieutenant's name was Jay Gatsby. For the next four years, I didn't see him again. In fact, at the end of those four years, when we were introduced in Long Island, I didn't even realize that he was that lieutenant.
es_translation: I was flattered that she wanted to talk to me, because out of all the older girls, she was the one I admired the most. She asked me if I was going to the Red Cross to make bandage packages. Yes, I was going to the Red Cross. Well, would I mind notifying them that she couldn't go that day? The officer was looking at Daisy while she spoke, in a way that any girl would wish to be looked at at least once, and that moment seemed so romantic to me that I haven't forgotten it. The officer's name was Jay Gatsby, and I didn't lay eyes on him again until four years later. Even when I ran into him again, in Long Island, I didn't realize it was the same man.

en: That was nineteen-seventeen. By the next year I had a few beaux myself, and I began to play in tournaments, so I didn’t see Daisy very often. She went with a slightly older crowd—when she went with anyone at all. Wild rumours were circulating about her—how her mother had found her packing her bag one winter night to go to New York and say goodbye to a soldier who was going overseas. She was effectually prevented, but she wasn’t on speaking terms with her family for several weeks. After that she didn’t play around with the soldiers any more, but only with a few flat-footed, shortsighted young men in town, who couldn’t get into the army at all.
vi: Năm đó là năm một ngàn chín trăm mười bẩy. Sang đến năm sau, em cũng đã có vài anh theo đuổi và em bắt đầu tham gia tranh giải. Bởi vậy em không còn gặp chị Daisy thường xuyên nữa. Chị Daisy ít chơi với ai, chỉ giao thiệp với những người lớn tuổi hơn chị một chút. Có những tin đồn dữ dội đồn đãi về chị, nói một tối mùa đông mẹ chị ấy đã khám phá ra hành lý của chị khi chị chuẩn bị đi New York từ biệt một quân nhân sắp sửa được bổ nhiệm ra nước ngoài. Chị ấy đã bị ngăn lại không cho đi. Chuyện này khiến chị không hề nói chuyện với mọi người trong nhà nhiều tuần. Sau đó, chị ấy không còn liên lạc với mấy quân nhân nữa mà chỉ giao thiệp với mấy người thanh niên địa phương vụng về, mắt cận thị không thể gia nhập quân đội.
tr: “Bu anlattığım 1917’de olmuştu. Bir yıl sonrasında artık benim de peşim­de birkaç hayranım vardı. Bu arada golf turnuvalarında oynamaya başlamıştım, bu nedenle Daisy’i pek az görür oldum. İnsan içine çıkarsa da, ancak bizden yaşça büyük arkadaşlarıyla beraber olurdu. Onu pek görmesek de, sürekli olarak hakkındaki çılgın dedikoduları işitirdik. Mesela söylenilenlere göre bir kış gecesi, deniz aşırı göreve gidecek olan bir subayla vedalaşmak için, New York’a gitmek üzere valizini hazırlarken annesine yaka­lanmıştı. Elbette gitmesine mani olunmuştu. Bunun üzerine Daisy’nin ailesine küsüp haftalarca konuşmadığı anlatılırdı. Hatta dedikoduya göre Daisy, o zamandan sonra bir daha hiçbir askerle görüşmemiş; yalnızca düztaban ya da miyop olduklarından askere alınmamış olan gençlerle çıkmıştı.
es: Aquello fue en 1917. Al año siguiente yo también tenía algunos admiradores, y empecé a participar en torneos, así que no vi mucho a Daisy. Ella salía con un grupo algo mayor, cuando salía con alguien. Circulaban rumores disparatados sobre ella, sobre cómo su madre la había descubierto preparando el equipaje para irse a Nueva York a despedir a un soldado destinado a ultramar. Se lo impidieron terminantemente, pero Daisy le retiró la palabra a su familia durante semanas. Desde entonces no volvió a tontear con los soldados, sólo con jóvenes cortos de vista o con los pies planos, inútiles para el servicio militar.
vi_translation: That year was the year one thousand nine hundred and seventeen. By the following year, I had a few suitors and I began to participate in competitions. Therefore, I no longer met Daisy frequently. Daisy rarely played with anyone, only socializing with those slightly older than her. There were fierce rumors about her, saying that one winter night her mother discovered her luggage as she was preparing to go to New York to bid farewell to a soldier about to be deployed overseas. She was stopped from going. This incident caused her not to speak to anyone in the house for many weeks. After that, she no longer kept in touch with the soldiers but only socialized with some clumsy local youths with nearsightedness who couldn't join the army.
tr_translation: “This happened in 1917. A year later, I had a few admirers following me. Meanwhile, I had started playing in golf tournaments, so I rarely saw Daisy. Even if she went out, she would only be with friends older than us. Although we didn't see her much, we constantly heard crazy rumors about her. For instance, according to what was said, one winter night, she was caught by her mother while packing her suitcase to go to New York to say goodbye to an officer who was going overseas. Of course, she was prevented from going. It was said that Daisy was so upset with her family that she didn't speak to them for weeks. According to the rumor, Daisy never saw another soldier after that; she only went out with young men who were flat-footed or nearsighted and thus not drafted.
es_translation: That was in 1917. The following year I also had some admirers, and I started participating in tournaments, so I didn't see much of Daisy. She hung out with a slightly older group, when she went out with anyone. Wild rumors circulated about her, about how her mother had caught her packing to go to New York to see off a soldier bound overseas. They absolutely forbade it, but Daisy didn't speak to her family for weeks. Since then, she didn't flirt with soldiers anymore, only with young men who were nearsighted or flat-footed, unfit for military service.

en: By the next autumn she was gay again, gay as ever. She had a début after the armistice, and in February she was presumably engaged to a man from New Orleans. In June she married Tom Buchanan of Chicago, with more pomp and circumstance than Louisville ever knew before. He came down with a hundred people in four private cars, and hired a whole floor of the Muhlbach Hotel, and the day before the wedding he gave her a string of pearls valued at three hundred and fifty thousand dollars.
vi: Sang đến mùa thu năm sau thì Daisy lại vui vẻ trở lại, vui vẻ bình thường như xưa. Chị thực sự bước chân ra đời sau khi ngưng chiến, sang đến tháng Hai thì chị ấy đính hôn với một người ở New Orleans. Nhưng sang tháng Sáu, thì lại đám cưới với Tom Buchanan người Chicago. Đám cưới xa hoa tráng lệ chưa từng có ở Lousiville. Tom đưa xuống cả trăm người trên bốn toa xe riêng và mướn nguyên cả từng lầu khách sạn Seelbach. Trước đám cưới một ngày anh ta tặng chị ấy một chuỗi ngọc trai giá trị lên đến ba trăm năm chục ngàn đô la.
tr: “Sonbaharda eski neşesine kavuşmuştu. Barışın imzalanmasının ardından, onuruna bir balo verilerek resmen sosye­teye tanıtıldı. Şubat ayında New Orleans’dan biriyle nişan­lanmış olduğunu işittik. Haziran’da ise Louisville’de, eşi benzeri görülmemiş, görkemli bir törenle Chicago’lu Tom Buchanan ile evlendi. Damat yanında yüz kişi ile birlikte, dört özel araçla geldi, Muhlbach Oteli’nin bir katını tamamen kapattı; törenden bir gece önce de, Daisy’e üç yüz elli bin dolarlık, inci bir gerdanlık taktı.
es: Para otoño ya estaba otra vez alegre, más alegre que nunca. Debutó en sociedad después del armisticio, y en febrero estaba prometida con un tipo de Nueva Orleans, o eso se dijo. En junio se casó con Tom Buchanan, de Chicago, con pompa y solemnidad nunca vistas en la historia de Louisville. El novio llegó con cien personas en cuatro vagones privados, y alquiló una planta entera del Hotel Muhlbach, y el día antes de la boda le regaló a la novia un collar de perlas valorado en trescientos cincuenta mil dólares.
vi_translation: By the following autumn, Daisy was cheerful again, as cheerful as she used to be. She truly stepped out into the world after the armistice, and by February, she was engaged to a man in New Orleans. But by June, she married Tom Buchanan from Chicago. The wedding was an unprecedentedly lavish and magnificent affair in Louisville. Tom brought down a hundred people in four private train cars and rented an entire floor of the Seelbach Hotel. The day before the wedding, he gave her a pearl necklace worth three hundred and fifty thousand dollars.
tr_translation: “In the fall, she regained her old cheerfulness. After the signing of the peace, a ball was held in her honor, and she was formally introduced to society. In February, we heard that she had gotten engaged to someone from New Orleans. In June, she married Tom Buchanan from Chicago in Louisville, in an unprecedented, magnificent ceremony. The groom arrived with a hundred people, in four private cars, and took over an entire floor of the Muhlbach Hotel; the night before the ceremony, he gave Daisy a pearl necklace worth three hundred and fifty thousand dollars.
es_translation: By autumn she was cheerful again, more cheerful than ever. She made her social debut after the armistice, and by February she was engaged to a guy from New Orleans, or so it was said. In June she married Tom Buchanan, from Chicago, with pomp and solemnity never before seen in the history of Louisville. The groom arrived with a hundred people in four private cars, and rented an entire floor of the Muhlbach Hotel, and the day before the wedding he gave the bride a pearl necklace valued at three hundred and fifty thousand dollars.

en: I was a bridesmaid. I came into her room half an hour before the bridal dinner, and found her lying on her bed as lovely as the June night in her flowered dress—and as drunk as a monkey. She had a bottle of Sauterne in one hand and a letter in the other.
vi: Em làm phụ dâu. Khoảng nửa tiếng trước khi bữa tiệc cưới khai mạc, em đến phòng Daisy và nhìn thấy chị đang nằm trên giường trong chiếc áo cưới hoa, xinh đẹp như một đêm tháng Sáu. Chị ấy say khướt, một tay cầm chai rượu Sauterne, tay kia cầm một lá thư.
tr: “Gelinin nedimelerindendim. Düğün yemeğinden yarım saat önce odasına çıktığımda, onu Haziran güneşi kadar alımlı göründüğü çiçekli elbisesinin içinde, yatağına uzanmış bir vaziyette buldum. Dut gibi sarhoştu; bir elinde bir Sauterne şişesi, diğer elinde ise bir mektup vardı.
es: Fui una de las damas de honor. Entré en el dormitorio de Daisy media hora antes de la cena de gala que precedió al día de la boda y me la encontré tendida en la cama, bella como una noche de junio en su vestido de flores… y totalmente borracha. Tenía una botella de Sauternes en una mano y una carta en la otra.
vi_translation: I was a bridesmaid. About half an hour before the wedding reception started, I went to Daisy's room and saw her lying on the bed in her floral wedding dress, beautiful as a June night. She was completely drunk, holding a bottle of Sauterne in one hand and a letter in the other.
tr_translation: “I was one of the bride's bridesmaids. When I went up to her room half an hour before the wedding dinner, I found her lying on her bed, looking as charming as the June sun in her floral dress. She was as drunk as a lord; in one hand she held a bottle of Sauterne, and in the other, a letter.
es_translation: I was one of the bridesmaids. I entered Daisy's bedroom half an hour before the gala dinner that preceded the wedding day and found her lying on the bed, beautiful as a June night in her floral dress... and completely drunk. She had a bottle of Sauternes in one hand and a letter in the other.

en: “ ’Gratulate me,” she muttered. “Never had a drink before, but oh how I do enjoy it.”
vi: "Chúc mừng cho chị đi." Chị ấy thì thầm. "Chị chưa bao giờ uống rượu trong đời, nhưng hôm nay chị uống thấy rất ngon."
tr: ‘Beni tebrik etmeyecek misin’ dedi dili dolanarak, ‘Bugüne kadar hiç içmemiştim, meğer ne güzel şeymiş.
es: —Feli… Felicítame —murmuró—. No había bebido nunca, pero me encanta.
vi_translation: "Congratulate me." She whispered. "I have never drunk alcohol in my life, but today I find it very delicious."
tr_translation: ‘Aren't you going to congratulate me?’ he said, slurring his words, ‘I had never drunk before, turns out it's such a nice thing.’
es_translation: —Congra… Congratulate me —he murmured—. I had never drunk before, but I love it.

en: “What’s the matter, Daisy?”
vi: "Chuyện gì đã xẩy ra, chị Daisy?"
tr: ‘Daisy, neyin var?
es: —¿Qué te pasa, Daisy?
vi_translation: "What happened, Daisy?"
tr_translation: ‘Daisy, what's wrong?’
es_translation: —What's wrong with you, Daisy?

en: I was scared, I can tell you; I’d never seen a girl like that before.
vi: Để em nói cho anh biết, lúc đó em rất sợ, em chưa từng thấy một người con gái ở trong tình trạng như vậy.
tr: “Çok korktuğumu itiraf etmeliyim, o ana kadar bir kızı hiç o halde görmemiştim.
es: Yo estaba asustada, de verdad. Nunca había visto así a una chica.
vi_translation: Let me tell you, at that moment I was very scared, I had never seen a girl in such a state.
tr_translation: “I must admit I was very scared; until that moment, I had never seen a girl in such a state.
es_translation: I was really scared. I had never seen a girl like that.

en: She began to cry—she cried and cried. I rushed out and found her mother’s maid, and we locked the door and got her into a cold bath. She wouldn’t let go of the letter. She took it into the tub with her and squeezed it up in a wet ball, and only let me leave it in the soap-dish when she saw that it was coming to pieces like snow.
vi: Chị ấy bắt đầu khóc, khóc và khóc mãi. Em chạy vội ra ngoài đi tìm người hầu gái. Hai chúng em khóa cửa lại và đưa Daisy vào tắm nước lạnh. Chị ấy nhất định không buông lá thư. Chị ấy mang nó vào theo bồn tắm và vò ném chặt cho tới khi nó biến thành một trái banh giấy sũng ướt. Cuối cùng khi nhìn thấy nó bắt đầu rửa ra từng miếng như hoa tuyết chị ấy mới để cho em đặt nó lên trên khay đựng xà bông.
tr: “Hıçkırıklara boğuldu; ağladı da ağladı. Dışarı fırladım, annesinin oda hizmetçisini buldum, sonra kapıyı kilitleyip Daisy’i soğuk duşun altına soktuk. Ancak elindeki mektubu bırakmaya ikna olmamış, banyoya da onunla girmişti. Ancak avucunda sıkıştırdığı ıslak mektup top haline gelip, parça parça dökülmeye başlayınca, o topağı elinden alıp sabunluğa koymama müsaade etmişti.
es: Se echó a llorar, y lloró, lloró. Salí corriendo y encontré a la criada de su madre. Cerramos la puerta con llave y la bañamos en agua fría. No se separaba de la carta. Se metió en la bañera con ella y la estrujó hasta convertirla en una bola húmeda, y sólo me dejó que la pusiera en la jabonera cuando vio que se estaba convirtiendo en copos de nieve.
vi_translation: She began to cry, cry, and cry endlessly. I rushed outside to find the maid. The two of us locked the door and gave Daisy a cold bath. She refused to let go of the letter. She took it into the bathtub and crumpled it tightly until it turned into a soaked paper ball. Finally, when she saw it starting to dissolve into pieces like snowflakes, she allowed me to place it on the soap dish.
tr_translation: “She was overcome with sobs; she cried and cried. I rushed outside, found her mother’s maid, then locked the door and put Daisy under a cold shower. However, she wasn’t convinced to let go of the letter in her hand and went into the bathroom with it. But when the wet letter she clutched in her palm turned into a soggy ball and started to fall apart, she allowed me to take it from her hand and place it on the soap dish.
es_translation: She burst into tears, and cried, cried. I ran out and found her mother's maid. We locked the door and bathed her in cold water. She wouldn't let go of the letter. She got into the bathtub with it and squeezed it until it turned into a wet ball, and only let me put it in the soap dish when she saw it was turning into snowflakes.

en: But she didn’t say another word. We gave her spirits of ammonia and put ice on her forehead and hooked her back into her dress, and half an hour later, when we walked out of the room, the pearls were around her neck and the incident was over. Next day at five o’clock she married Tom Buchanan without so much as a shiver, and started off on a three months’ trip to the South Seas.
vi: Thế nhưng sau đó chị ấy không hề nói thêm một lời. Chúng em cho chị ấy ấy ngửi một chút ammomia, trườm đá lên trán và mặc áo trở lại cho chị. Chỉ nửa tiếng sau, khi chúng em bước ra khỏi phòng thì chuỗi ngọc trai đã được đeo vào cổ và sự việc coi như đã xong. Năm giờ ngày hôm sau, chị ấy đám cưới với Tom Buchanan không một chút rùng mình và bắt đầu một chuyến du lịch ba tháng tới biển Nam South Sea.
tr: “Ardından tek kelime olsun konuşmadı. Ona amonyak koklattık, başına buz torbası koyduk, sonra da elbisesini giydirdik. Yarım saat sonra, boynunda inci gerdanlığıyla odasından beraber çıktık, mevzu kapanmıştı. Ertesi gün akşamüstü, saat beşte, sesi dahi titremeden Tom Buchanan’la evlendi. Ardından kocasıyla Güney Pasifik’e, üç ay sürecek balayı tatiline çıktı.
es: Pero no volvió a pronunciar palabra. La hicimos oler amoniaco, le pusimos hielo en la frente y la volvimos a meter en el vestido, y media hora más tarde, cuando salimos del dormitorio, el collar de perlas lucía en el cuello de Daisy y el incidente había acabado. Al día siguiente, a las cinco de la tarde, se casó con Tom Buchanan sin la menor vacilación y emprendió un viaje de tres meses por los Mares del Sur.
vi_translation: However, after that, she did not say another word. We let her smell a bit of ammonia, applied ice to her forehead, and put her clothes back on. Only half an hour later, when we stepped out of the room, the pearl necklace was already around her neck, and the matter was considered resolved. At five o'clock the next day, she married Tom Buchanan without a shiver and began a three-month trip to the South Sea.
tr_translation: “Then she didn't speak a single word. We made her smell ammonia, put an ice pack on her head, and then dressed her. Half an hour later, we left her room together with her wearing a pearl necklace, and the matter was closed. The next day in the afternoon, at five o'clock, she married Tom Buchanan without even a tremor in her voice. Then she went on a three-month honeymoon trip to the South Pacific with her husband.
es_translation: But she did not speak another word. We made her smell ammonia, put ice on her forehead, and got her back into the dress, and half an hour later, when we left the bedroom, the pearl necklace was shining on Daisy's neck and the incident was over. The next day, at five in the afternoon, she married Tom Buchanan without the slightest hesitation and embarked on a three-month trip through the South Seas.

en: I saw them in Santa Barbara when they came back, and I thought I’d never seen a girl so mad about her husband. If he left the room for a minute she’d look around uneasily, and say: “Where’s Tom gone?” and wear the most abstracted expression until she saw him coming in the door. She used to sit on the sand with his head in her lap by the hour, rubbing her fingers over his eyes and looking at him with unfathomable delight. It was touching to see them together—it made you laugh in a hushed, fascinated way. That was in August. A week after I left Santa Barbara Tom ran into a wagon on the Ventura road one night, and ripped a front wheel off his car. The girl who was with him got into the papers, too, because her arm was broken—she was one of the chambermaids in the Santa Barbara Hotel.
vi: Em gặp lại vợ chồng họ ở Santa Barbara khi họ trở về và em cho rằng em chưa bao giờ từng thấy người con gái nào quá say đắm với chồng của mình như chị. Mỗi khi anh ấy đi ra khỏi phòng chỉ chừng một phút thì chị ấy lại nhìn quanh trông như rất khó chịu. Chị sẽ hỏi. "Tom đi đâu rồi?" và tỏ ra rất lơ đãng cho tới khi trông thấy anh ấy quay trở lại cửa. Chị ấy thường ngồi trên cát đặt đầu của chồng lên đùi mình hằng giờ. Ngón tay vuốt nhẹ trên đôi mắt của anh ấy và nhìn anh ấy bằng một cái nhìn vui mừng không sao hiểu thấu. Cảnh tượng hai người họ ở bên nhau vừa làm cho ta xúc động, vừa làm cho ta phải cười thầm thú vị. Lúc đó là vào tháng Tám. Một tuần sau khi em rời Santa Barbara, một tối Tom chạy xe đụng vào một chiếc xe có khoang chở hàng ở trên đường Ventura, chiếc bánh xe của anh ấy rơi hẳn ra ngoài. Người con gái ở bên anh ấy lúc đó cũng bị đưa lên báo bởi vì cánh tay của cô ta bị gẫy. Hóa ra cô ta là một trong những cô hầu phòng ở khách sạn Santa Barbara.
tr: “Dönüşlerinin ardından, Santa Barbara’da görüştüğümüz vakit, kocasını bu denli seven başka bir kız olamayacağını düşünmüştüm. Tom bir dakikalığına olsun odadan çıksa huzursuzlanır, sağına soluna bakınarak Tom’u aramaya başlar, yüzündeki o ifade ise adam yeniden odaya dönene kadar silinmezdi. Kumsalda, Daisy Tom’u dizine yatırır, saatlerce adamın göz kapaklarında parmaklarını gezdirir, dokunurken de sonsuz bir aşkla onun yüzünü izlerdi. Onları beraber gördüğünüzde etkilenirdiniz. Gerçi biraz gülünç gelirdi ancak yine de halleri büyülerdi insanı. Bu anlattıklarım Ağustos ayında oluyordu. Santa Barbara’dan ayrıldıktan bir süre sonra Tom’un, Ventura yolunda bir araba kazası geçirdiğini okudum. Arabasının ön tekerleği fırlamıştı; gazeteler haliyle yanındaki, kolu kırılmış olan kızdan da bahsediyordu – bu kız kaldıkları otelin kat hizmetlilerinden biriydi.
es: Los vi en Santa Bárbara cuando volvieron, y pensé que jamás había visto a una chica tan loca por su marido. Si Tom salía un momento de la habitación, Daisy miraba a su alrededor nerviosa y decía: «¿Adónde ha ido Tom?», y se quedaba como ausente hasta que lo veía entrar por la puerta. Se sentaba en la arena con la cabeza de Tom en el regazo durante horas, acariciándole los ojos con los dedos y mirándolo con insondable placer. Era conmovedor verlos juntos: hacía que te rieras, en silencio, de fascinación. Era agosto. Una semana después de que me fuera de Santa Bárbara, Tom chocó con una furgoneta en la carretera de Ventura una noche, y perdió una de las ruedas delanteras de su coche. La chica que iba con él también salió en los periódicos, porque se rompió un brazo: era una de las camareras del Hotel Santa Bárbara.
vi_translation: I met the couple again in Santa Barbara when they returned, and I thought I had never seen a woman so passionately in love with her husband as she was. Whenever he left the room for just about a minute, she would look around seeming very uneasy. She would ask. "Where did Tom go?" and appear very absent-minded until she saw him return through the door. She often sat on the sand with her husband's head resting on her lap for hours. Her fingers gently stroked his eyes, and she looked at him with an incomprehensible joyful gaze. The sight of the two of them together was both touching and amusing. It was August then. A week after I left Santa Barbara, one evening Tom crashed his car into a truck on Ventura Road, and his wheel completely fell off. The girl who was with him at that time also made it to the news because her arm was broken. It turned out she was one of the maids at the Santa Barbara hotel.
tr_translation: "After their return, when we met in Santa Barbara, I thought there couldn't be another girl who loved her husband as much as she did. If Tom left the room even for a minute, she would become restless, looking around for Tom, and that expression on her face wouldn't fade until he returned to the room. On the beach, Daisy would lay Tom's head on her lap, run her fingers over his eyelids for hours, and watch his face with infinite love as she touched him. You would be impressed when you saw them together. It might seem a bit ridiculous, but their demeanor would still captivate you. This was happening in August. Shortly after leaving Santa Barbara, I read that Tom had a car accident on the Ventura road. The front wheel of his car had come off; naturally, the newspapers also mentioned the girl with a broken arm who was with him – this girl was one of the maids at the hotel they were staying at.
es_translation: I saw them in Santa Barbara when they returned, and I thought I had never seen a girl so crazy about her husband. If Tom left the room for a moment, Daisy would look around nervously and say, "Where has Tom gone?" and she would remain absent-minded until she saw him come back through the door. She would sit on the sand with Tom's head in her lap for hours, stroking his eyes with her fingers and looking at him with unfathomable pleasure. It was touching to see them together: it made you silently laugh with fascination. It was August. A week after I left Santa Barbara, Tom crashed into a van on the Ventura road one night, and lost one of the front wheels of his car. The girl who was with him also made the newspapers, because she broke an arm: she was one of the waitresses from the Santa Barbara Hotel.

en: The next April Daisy had her little girl, and they went to France for a year. I saw them one spring in Cannes, and later in Deauville, and then they came back to Chicago to settle down. Daisy was popular in Chicago, as you know. They moved with a fast crowd, all of them young and rich and wild, but she came out with an absolutely perfect reputation. Perhaps because she doesn’t drink. It’s a great advantage not to drink among hard-drinking people. You can hold your tongue and, moreover, you can time any little irregularity of your own so that everybody else is so blind that they don’t see or care. Perhaps Daisy never went in for amour at all—and yet there’s something in that voice of hers…
vi: Tháng Tư năm sau Daisy sanh đứa con gái, và họ sau đó đi sang bên Pháp ở khoảng một năm. Em gặp họ một mùa xuân ở Cannes, sau đó thì gặp ở Deauville, và rồi sau đó họ quay về Chicago sống ổn định ở đó. Daisy rất được nhiều người biết đến ở Chicago, như anh biết đó. Hai người họ thường tụ tập với những người ăn chơi trẻ tuổi, giàu có và sống điên cuồng, thế nhưng giữa đám người họ Daisy lúc nào cũng giữ thanh danh. Có lẽ là tại vì chị ấy không uống rượu. Không uống rượu giữa đám người uống như hũ chìm cũng là một điều lợi. Mình có thể giữ mồm miệng, hơn nữa, mình có thể làm những việc hơi khác thường một chút mà không ai nhận ra hay quan tâm. Có lẽ Daisy đã chưa bao giờ dính líu vào một chuyện tình bất chính, nhưng có một cái gì đó trong giọng nói của chị...
tr: “Nisanda Daisy dünyaya bir kız çocuğu getirdi ve ailece bir yıllığına Fransa’ya gittiler. Onlarla bir bahar günü Cannes’ta, daha sonra ise Deauville’de karşılaştım. Sonra aile Chicago’ya döndü ve oraya yerleşti. Sen de bilirsin, Daisy orada çok sevilirdi. Çevresinde hep, zengin, genç, hızlı yaşayan ve çılgın tipler vardı. Yine de ismi, belki de içki içmediğindendir, hiçbir skandala karışmadı. Çok içen insanların yanında ayık kalmak her zaman faydalıdır. Her şeyden önce dilinizi bağlar, fazla gevezelik etmezsiniz. Daha da güzeli insanın kendi kusur ve yanlışlarını örtebilmesidir, nasılsa kimsenin sizi görecek hali olmaz. Zira görseler de umursamazlar. Daisy belki de bir aşk macerasına hiç karışmamıştı. (Bunu söylerken sesinde bir şeyler vardı sanki)
es: En abril del año siguiente Daisy tuvo una niña, y se fueron a Francia un año. Los vi una primavera en Cannes, y más tarde en Deauville, antes de que volvieran a Chicago, donde se instalaron. Daisy tenía mucho éxito en Chicago, como sabes. Entraban y salían con un grupo al que le gustaba divertirse, todos jóvenes, ricos y desenfrenados, pero la reputación de Daisy quedó perfectamente a salvo. Quizá porque no bebe. Es una gran ventaja no beber entre gente que bebe mucho. No hablas de más y en el momento oportuno puedes permitirte alguna irregularidad menor pues todos están tan ciegos que ni se dan cuenta o no les importa. Puede que Daisy jamás se metiera en amoríos… pero con esa voz que tiene…
vi_translation: In April of the following year, Daisy gave birth to a baby girl, and they then went to live in France for about a year. I met them one spring in Cannes, then in Deauville, and afterwards they returned to Chicago to settle down there. Daisy was very well-known in Chicago, as you know. The two of them often gathered with young, wealthy, and wild party-goers, but among them, Daisy always maintained her reputation. Perhaps it was because she didn't drink alcohol. Not drinking among heavy drinkers is also an advantage. You can keep your mouth shut, and moreover, you can do slightly unusual things without anyone noticing or caring. Perhaps Daisy had never been involved in an illicit affair, but there was something in her voice...
tr_translation: “In April, Daisy gave birth to a baby girl and the family went to France for a year. I met them one spring day in Cannes, and later in Deauville. Then the family returned to Chicago and settled there. You know, Daisy was very well-liked there. She was always surrounded by rich, young, fast-living, and wild types. Still, her name was never involved in any scandal, perhaps because she didn't drink. It's always beneficial to stay sober around people who drink a lot. First of all, it ties your tongue, so you don't talk too much. Even better, it allows you to cover up your own faults and mistakes, as no one is in a state to notice you anyway. Because even if they see, they don't care. Daisy perhaps never got involved in a love affair. (There was something in her voice when she said this)
es_translation: In April of the following year, Daisy had a baby girl, and they went to France for a year. I saw them one spring in Cannes, and later in Deauville, before they returned to Chicago, where they settled down. Daisy was very successful in Chicago, as you know. They mingled with a group that liked to have fun, all young, rich, and reckless, but Daisy's reputation remained perfectly intact. Perhaps because she doesn't drink. It's a great advantage not to drink among people who drink a lot. You don't talk too much and at the right moment you can afford some minor indiscretion because everyone is so blind that they either don't notice or don't care. Maybe Daisy never got involved in affairs... but with that voice she has...

en: Well, about six weeks ago, she heard the name Gatsby for the first time in years. It was when I asked you—do you remember?—if you knew Gatsby in West Egg. After you had gone home she came into my room and woke me up, and said: “What Gatsby?” and when I described him—I was half asleep—she said in the strangest voice that it must be the man she used to know. It wasn’t until then that I connected this Gatsby with the officer in her white car.
