Theo lời chỉ của thằng bé gác thang máy, tôi đẩy cửa căn phòng đề chữ "Công ty Swatika", dường như không có ai ở trong đó. Nhưn khi tôi lớn tiếng gọi hello nhiều lần tưởng như vô vọng thì tôi nghe có tiếng cãi vã phía sau bức bình phong, sau đó một phụ nữ người Do Thái xinh đẹp xuất hiện từ phía cửa bên trong, nhìn tôi dò xét với đôi mắt đen không thiện cảm.
tr: Cenaze gününün sabahında New York’a Meyer Wolfsheim’ı gör­meye gittim; ona başka şekilde ulaşamayacakmışım gibi görünüyordu. Asansörcü çocuğun yönlendirdiği kapının üzerinde ‘Swastika Holding’ yazıyordu: kapıyı iterek içeri girdiğimde, kimsenin olmadığını gördüm. Birkaç defa ‘Merhaba’ diye boşuna seslendim, derken bölmelerin arkasından bir takım tartışma sesleri geldiğini fark ettim, hemen ardından da içerdeki odalardan birinden bir Yahudi güzeli çıkıp siyah gözleriyle, düşmanca bir tavırla be­ni süzdü.
es: La mañana del funeral fui a Nueva York a ver a Meyer Wolfshiem; parecía no haber otro modo de localizarlo. En la puerta que abrí, siguiendo las instrucciones del ascensorista, había un rótulo en el que se leía The Swastika Holding Company, y al principio creí que no había nadie. Pero, después de gritar «Buenos días» en vano varias veces, empezaron a discutir en la habitación contigua y al momento apareció en una puerta interior una judía muy atractiva y me examinó con unos ojos negros y hostiles.
vi_translation: On the morning of the funeral, I went to New York to meet Meyer Wolfsheim; otherwise, I truly had no other option. Following the directions of the elevator boy, I pushed open the door marked "Swatika Company," and it seemed there was no one inside. But when I loudly called "hello" several times, almost in vain, I heard arguing behind a screen. Then a beautiful Jewish woman appeared from the inner door, scrutinizing me with unfriendly dark eyes.
tr_translation: On the morning of the funeral, I went to New York to see Meyer Wolfsheim; it seemed like I couldn't reach him any other way. On the door directed by the elevator boy, it said 'Swastika Holding': when I pushed the door and entered, I saw that no one was there. I called out 'Hello' a few times in vain, then I noticed some arguing voices coming from behind the partitions, and immediately after, a beautiful Jewish woman came out from one of the inner rooms and scrutinized me with her black eyes, with a hostile attitude.
es_translation: The morning of the funeral I went to New York to see Meyer Wolfshiem; there seemed to be no other way to locate him. On the door that I opened, following the elevator operator's instructions, there was a sign that read The Swastika Holding Company, and at first, I thought there was no one there. But, after shouting "Good morning" in vain several times, an argument started in the adjoining room and soon a very attractive Jewish woman appeared at an interior door and examined me with black, hostile eyes.

en: The first part of this was obviously untrue, for someone had begun to whistle “The Rosary,” tunelessly, inside.
vi: Phần đầu của câu nói rõ ràng là không đúng, bởi vì ngay khi đó bên trong có tiếng ai đó huýt sáo không đúng điệu bài "The Rosary".
tr: Ancak söylediklerinin yalan olduğu hemen ortaya çıkmıştı, çünkü içerden birileri ‘Rosary’ adlı şarkıyı ahenksiz bir ıslıkla çalmaya başlamıştı.
es: Lo primero era evidentemente falso, porque dentro alguien había empezado a silbar desafinando El rosario[24].
vi_translation: The first part of the statement is clearly incorrect, because at that moment there was the sound of someone whistling off-key to the tune of "The Rosary" inside.
tr_translation: However, it immediately became apparent that what they were saying was a lie, because someone inside had started to play the song 'Rosary' with a discordant whistle.
es_translation: The first thing was evidently false, because inside someone had started whistling out of tune The rosary[24].

en: “Please say that Mr. Carraway wants to see him.”
vi: "Làm ơn nhắn lại rằng có anh Carraway đến tìm ông ta."
tr: “Kendisine lütfen Bay Carraway’in onu görmek istediğini söyleyin.
es: —Haga el favor de decirle que mister Carraway quiere verlo.
vi_translation: "Please let him know that Mr. Carraway is here to see him."
tr_translation: "Please tell him that Mr. Carraway wants to see him."
es_translation: —Please do me the favor of telling him that Mr. Carraway wants to see him.

en: “I can’t get him back from Chicago, can I?”
vi: "Tôi không có cách nào khiến ông ấy quay về từ Chicago."
tr: “Onu Chicago’dan getiremem mümkün mü sizce?
es: —¿Voy a buscarlo a Chicago?
vi_translation: "I have no way to make him come back from Chicago."
tr_translation: “Do you think it’s possible for me to bring him from Chicago?
es_translation: —Am I going to look for him in Chicago?

en: At this moment a voice, unmistakably Wolfshiem’s, called “Stella!” from the other side of the door.
vi: Ngay lúc đó một giọng nói cất lên gọi từ phía sau bên kia cánh cửa "Stella!", không lầm lẫn vào đâu, đó là giọng của Wolfsheim.
tr: Tam o sırada kapının ardından biri “Stella” diye ses­lendi, bunun Wolfsheim’ın sesi olduğu şüphe götürmezdi.
es: En ese momento una voz, inequívocamente la de mister Wolfshiem, gritó «¡Estella!» al otro lado de la puerta.
vi_translation: At that moment, a voice called out from behind the door, "Stella!" There was no mistaking it, it was Wolfsheim's voice.
tr_translation: Just then, someone called out “Stella” from behind the door, and it was undoubtedly Wolfsheim’s voice.
es_translation: At that moment a voice, unmistakably that of Mr. Wolfshiem, shouted "Estella!" from the other side of the door.

en: “Leave your name on the desk,” she said quickly. “I’ll give it to him when he gets back.”
vi: "Cứ để danh thiếp của anh lại trên bàn, tôi sẽ chuyển cho ông ta một khi ông ta về đây." Bà ta nói một cách vội vã.
tr: “Kartınızı masaya bırakın, döner dönmez kendisine mutlaka veririm” dedi çabucak.
es: —Déjeme su nombre en la mesa —dijo ella—. Le daré el recado en cuanto vuelva.
vi_translation: "Just leave your business card on the table, I will hand it to him once he returns." She said hurriedly.
tr_translation: "Leave your card on the table, I will definitely give it to him as soon as he returns," he said quickly.
es_translation: —Leave your name on the table —she said—. I will give him the message as soon as he returns.

en: “But I know he’s there.”
vi: "Nhưng tôi biết ông ta đang ở trong đó."
tr: “Fakat kendisinin içeride olduğunu biliyorum.
es: —Pero sé que está aquí.
vi_translation: "But I know he is in there."
tr_translation: “But I know that he is inside.”
es_translation: —But I know it's here.

en: She took a step toward me and began to slide her hands indignantly up and down her hips.
vi: Bà ta bước tới thêm một bước về phía tôi, hai tay đưa lên xuống vuốt hông đầy phẫn nộ.
tr: Bir adım yaklaşıp ellerini öfkeyle kaldırdı, hemen sonra kalçalarına dayayıp, “Siz gençler, canınız her istediğinde buraya damlayabileceğinizi sanıyordunuz,” diyerek azarladı, “Artık bıktık usandık!
es: Dio un paso hacia mí y empezó a pasarse las manos por las caderas, arriba y abajo.
vi_translation: She took another step towards me, her hands moving up and down her hips in anger.
tr_translation: He took a step closer and raised his hands in anger, then placed them on his hips and scolded, "You young people thought you could drop by here whenever you wanted," saying, "We are fed up and tired of it!
es_translation: He took a step towards me and started running his hands up and down his hips.

en: “You young men think you can force your way in here any time,” she scolded. “We’re getting sickantired of it. When I say he’s in Chicago, he’s in Chicago.”
vi: "Mấy người trẻ như anh nghĩ anh có thể xông vào đây bất cứ lúc nào à." Bà ta mắng mỏ. "Chúng tôi thật quá chán ngán mệt mỏi kiểu như vậy rồi. Khi tôi nói ông ta đang ở Chicago, thì đúng là ông ta đang ở Chicago."
tr: Bir adım yaklaşıp ellerini öfkeyle kaldırdı, hemen sonra kalçalarına dayayıp, “Siz gençler, canınız her istediğinde buraya damlayabileceğinizi sanıyordunuz,” diyerek azarladı, “Artık bıktık usandık! Chicago’da diyorsam, Chicago’dadır.
es: —Ustedes, los jóvenes, se creen que pueden entrar aquí cuando les da la gana —me regañó—. Y nos tienen hartos, hasta la náusea. Cuando digo que está en Chicago, está en Chicago.
vi_translation: "Young people like you think you can barge in here anytime you want." She scolded. "We are really too fed up and tired of this kind of thing already." "When I say he is in Chicago, he is indeed in Chicago."
tr_translation: He took a step closer and raised his hands in anger, then placed them on his hips and scolded, "You young people thought you could drop by here whenever you wanted," saying, "We are fed up and tired of it! If I say it's in Chicago, it's in Chicago."
es_translation: —You young people think you can come in here whenever you feel like it —he scolded me—. And we're fed up with it, to the point of nausea. When I say he's in Chicago, he's in Chicago.

en: I mentioned Gatsby.
vi: Tôi nhắc tới tên của Gatsby.
tr: Ona Gatsby’den bahsettim.
es: Mencioné a Gatsby.
vi_translation: I mentioned Gatsby's name.
tr_translation: I told her about Gatsby.
es_translation: I mentioned Gatsby.

en: “Oh-h!” She looked at me over again. “Will you just—What was your name?”
vi: "Ồ....." Bà ta nhìn tôi một lần nữa. "Nếu vậy thì xin anh....
tr: “A! Beni bir kez daha süzdükten sonra, “Bir dakika… İsminiz neydi?
es: —Ah —volvió a mirarme—. Podría… ¿Me repite su nombre?
vi_translation: "Oh....." She looked at me once more. "If that's the case, then please....
tr_translation: "Ah!" After scrutinizing me once more, “One moment... What was your name?”
es_translation: —Ah —he looked at me again—. Could you… repeat your name for me?

en: She vanished. In a moment Meyer Wolfshiem stood solemnly in the doorway, holding out both hands. He drew me into his office, remarking in a reverent voice that it was a sad time for all of us, and offered me a cigar.
vi: Tên anh là gì nhỉ?" Bà ta lập tức biến đi, một lát sau Meyer Wolfsheim xuất hiện, đứng một cách trịnh trọng ở cửa, đưa cả hai tay ra đón tôi. Ông ta dẫn tôi vào trong văn phòng, nói với tôi giọng đầy kính trọng rằng đây là thời gian đau buồn cho tất cả mọi người. Sau đó ông ta mời tôi một điếu xì gà.
tr: Ortadan kayboldu. Çok geçmeden Meyer Wolfsheim, yüzünde vakur bir ifadeyle kapıda belirdi, iki elini uzatarak yaklaştı. Elimi ellerinin arasına alarak saygılı bir sesle, bugünlerin hepimiz için kederli ve zor günler olduğunu söyledi, ardından beni ofisine götürüp bir puro ikram etti.
es: Se esfumó. Al instante apareció solemnemente en la puerta Meyer Wolfshiem, tendiéndome las dos manos. Me hizo entrar en su despacho mientras comentaba con voz reverente que era un momento muy triste para todos nosotros, y me ofreció un cigarro.
vi_translation: What is your name?" She immediately disappeared, and a moment later Meyer Wolfsheim appeared, standing solemnly at the door, extending both hands to welcome me. He led me into the office, speaking to me with great respect, saying that this was a time of sorrow for everyone. Then he offered me a cigar.
tr_translation: He disappeared. Soon after, Meyer Wolfsheim appeared at the door with a dignified expression on his face, extending both hands as he approached. Taking my hand between his, he said in a respectful voice that these days were sorrowful and difficult for all of us, then took me to his office and offered me a cigar.
es_translation: He vanished. At that moment, Meyer Wolfshiem solemnly appeared at the door, extending both hands to me. He led me into his office while commenting in a reverent voice that it was a very sad time for all of us, and he offered me a cigar.

en: “My memory goes back to when first I met him,” he said. “A young major just out of the army and covered over with medals he got in the war. He was so hard up he had to keep on wearing his uniform because he couldn’t buy some regular clothes. First time I saw him was when he came into Winebrenner’s poolroom at Forty-third Street and asked for a job. He hadn’t eat anything for a couple of days. ‘Come on have some lunch with me,’ I said. He ate more than four dollars’ worth of food in half an hour.”
vi: "Tôi vẫn nhớ lần đầu tiên khi tôi gặp anh ta. Lúc đó anh ta là một thiếu tá vừa mới giải ngũ, trên người vẫn còn đeo đầy những huân chương có được trong chiến tranh. Anh ta nghèo đến nỗi không mua nổi cho mình quần áo thường phục để mặc mà cứ phải mặc những bộ quân phục như vậy. Lần đầu tiên khi tôi gặp anh ta là khi anh ta đến tiệm bi-da Winebrenner ở đường Forty để xin việc. Đã hai ba ngày anh ta chưa ăn gì. Tôi mời 'đến đây ăn trưa với tôi'. Chỉ trong nửa giờ đồng hồ, anh ta đã ăn hết cả bốn đồng đô-la tiền đồ ăn."
tr: “Onunla ilk tanıştığımız günü hatırlıyorum da” dedi. “Göğ­sü savaşta kazandığı madalyalarla dolu olan, yeni terhis olmuş, genç bir binbaşıydı. Öyle dardaydı ki, gündelik kıyafete verecek parası olmadığından, üniformayla dolaşırdı. Onu ilk gördüğümde 43’üncü Caddedeki Winebrenner bilardo salonuna iş istemeye gelmişti. İki gündür boğazından tek lokma geçmemişti. ‘Gel birlikte yiyelim,’ demiştim. Dört dolarlık yiyeceği yarım saat içersinde silip süpürmüştü.
es: —La memoria me lleva al día en que lo conocí —dijo—. Un mayor, muy joven, recién licenciado y cubierto de medallas que había ganado en la guerra. No tenía ni un centavo: seguía usando el uniforme porque no tenía dinero para comprarse ropa. Lo vi por primera vez en los billares de Winebrenner, en la calle Cuarenta y tres, donde entró a pedir trabajo. No comía desde hacía dos días. «Véngase a almorzar conmigo», le dije. Devoró más de cuatro dólares de comida en media hora.
vi_translation: "I still remember the first time I met him. At that time, he was a recently discharged major, still wearing all the medals he had earned in the war. He was so poor that he couldn't afford civilian clothes and had to keep wearing his military uniform. The first time I met him was when he came to the Winebrenner billiard hall on Forty Street to ask for a job. He hadn't eaten anything for two or three days. I invited him to 'come have lunch with me'. In just half an hour, he had eaten four dollars' worth of food."
tr_translation: “I remember the day we first met,” he said. “He was a young major, freshly discharged, with his chest full of medals earned in the war. He was so hard up that he couldn't afford civilian clothes and walked around in his uniform. When I first saw him, he had come to the Winebrenner billiard hall on 43rd Street to ask for a job. He hadn't had a bite to eat for two days. ‘Come, let's eat together,’ I had said. He devoured four dollars' worth of food in half an hour.”
es_translation: —Memory takes me back to the day I met him —he said—. A major, very young, recently discharged and covered in medals he had won in the war. He didn't have a cent: he kept wearing the uniform because he didn't have money to buy clothes. I saw him for the first time at Winebrenner's billiards, on Forty-third Street, where he came in to ask for a job. He hadn't eaten for two days. «Come have lunch with me», I said to him. He devoured more than four dollars' worth of food in half an hour.

en: “Did you start him in business?” I inquired.
vi: "Ông đã giúp anh ta bắt đầu sự nghiệp à ?" Tôi gạn hỏi.
tr: “Onu işe aldınız mı?” diye sordum
es: —¿Lo introdujo usted en los negocios?
vi_translation: "Did you help him start his career?" I probed.
tr_translation: "Did you hire him?" I asked
es_translation: —Did you introduce him to the business?

en: “Start him! I made him.”
vi: "Giúp anh ta bắt đầu? Thật ra chính tôi đã gầy dựng nên anh ta."
tr: “İşe almakla kalmadım! Onu ben yarattım-”
es: —¡Introducirlo! Yo lo hice un hombre de negocios.
vi_translation: "Help him get started? Actually, I was the one who built him up."
tr_translation: "I didn't just hire him! I created him-"
es_translation: —Introduce him! I made him a businessman.

en: “I raised him up out of nothing, right out of the gutter. I saw right away he was a fine-appearing, gentlemanly young man, and when he told me he was at Oggsford I knew I could use him good. I got him to join the American Legion and he used to stand high there. Right off he did some work for a client of mine up to Albany. We were so thick like that in everything”—he held up two bulbous fingers—“always together.”
vi: "Tôi đã moi anh ta lên từ con số không, moi ra khỏi từ ống cống. Tôi nhận ra ngay lập tức anh ta là một thanh niên tuấn tú, bạch thiệp, rồi khi anh ta nói and đã từng học ở Oxford, tôi biết tôi có chỗ để dùng anh ta. Tôi đưa anh ta gia nhập vào hội cựu chiến binh Hoa Kỳ, ở đó anh ta có địa vị rất cao trong hội. Lúc khởi đầu, anh ta giúp việc cho một khách hàng của tôi ở Albany. Chúng tôi đã gắn bó với nhau như thế này trong tất cả mọi thứ." Wolfsheim dơ hai ngón tay hình củ chuối của mình lên, "lúc nào cũng sát cánh bên nhau."
tr: “Yoktan var ettim onu, bataktan çekip kurtardım. Aslında iyi görünümlü genç bir centilmen olduğu daha ilk bakışta fark ediliyordu; üstelik Oggsford’da okumuş olduğunu duyunca bana da fayda getireceğinden emin oldum. Onu Amerikan Lejyonuna soktum, orada da kendini göstererek saygınlık kazandı, hemen Albany’den bir müşterimin işini çözdü. Kaynaştık, etle tırnak gibi olduk. İşte böyleydik!” son kelimeyi söylerken iki tombul parmağını birbirine yanaştırıp gösterdi, “anlayacağın, su sızmazdı aramızdan.
es: —Lo saqué de la nada, directamente del arroyo. Me di cuenta enseguida de que era un joven con buena apariencia y aires de señor, y cuando me dijo que había estado en Oggsford supe que podía serme muy útil. Le aconsejé que se afiliara a la Legión Americana, donde estaba muy bien considerado. Hizo entonces un trabajo para uno de mis clientes, en Albany. Estábamos así de unidos —levantó dos dedos bulbosos—, siempre juntos.
vi_translation: "I pulled him up from nothing, dragged him out of the gutter. I immediately recognized that he was a handsome, courteous young man, and when he said he had studied at Oxford, I knew I had a place to use him. I got him to join the American Legion, where he held a very high position. At the beginning, he worked for one of my clients in Albany. "We have been close like this in everything." Wolfsheim raised his two banana-shaped fingers, "always side by side."
tr_translation: “I created him from nothing, pulled him out of the mire. It was evident at first glance that he was actually a well-groomed young gentleman; moreover, when I heard he had studied at Oggsford, I was sure he would benefit me as well. I got him into the American Legion, where he also proved himself and gained respect, immediately solving a client's issue from Albany. We bonded, became inseparable. That's how we were!” he said, bringing his two chubby fingers together to show, “as you can understand, nothing could come between us.”
es_translation: —I pulled him out of nowhere, straight from the gutter. I immediately realized he was a young man with good looks and a gentlemanly air, and when he told me he had been at Oggsford, I knew he could be very useful to me. I advised him to join the American Legion, where he was highly regarded. He then did a job for one of my clients in Albany. We were this close —he raised two bulbous fingers—, always together.

en: I wondered if this partnership had included the World’s Series transaction in 1919.
vi: Tôi tự hỏi trong lòng không biết tình hợp tác đó của hai người có bao gồm cả việc sắp đặt trước trận vô địch bóng cà na năm 1919.
tr: 1919 Dünya Kupası’na karıştırılan şikede de ortaklıkları olup olmadığını merak ediyordum.
es: Me pregunté si aquella sociedad habría incluido la operación de las Grandes Ligas de béisbol en 1919.
vi_translation: I wonder in my heart whether that cooperation between the two included arranging the 1919 football championship in advance.
tr_translation: I was wondering if they had any involvement in the match-fixing scandal of the 1919 World Cup.
es_translation: I wondered if that society had included the operation of Major League Baseball in 1919.

en: “Now he’s dead,” I said after a moment. “You were his closest friend, so I know you’ll want to come to his funeral this afternoon.”
vi: "Bây giờ anh ta đã qua đời." Sau một lát, tôi nói. "Ông là bạn thân nhất của Gatsby, cho nên tôi biết ông sẽ muốn tới dự đám tang của Gatsy vào chiều nay."
tr: “Artık yaşamıyor,” dedim bir dakika sonra, “Onun en yakın dostu olarak sizin bugün öğleden sonraki cenaze töreninde bulunacağınızdan eminim.
es: —Y ahora está muerto —dijo al cabo de unos segundos—. Usted era su amigo más íntimo, así que sé que quiere que vaya al funeral esta tarde.
vi_translation: "Now he has passed away." After a moment, I said. "You were Gatsby's closest friend, so I know you will want to attend Gatsby's funeral this afternoon."
tr_translation: “He is no longer alive,” I said a minute later, “As his closest friend, I am sure you will be at the funeral ceremony this afternoon.”
es_translation: —And now he is dead —he said after a few seconds—. You were his closest friend, so I know you want me to go to the funeral this afternoon.

en: “I’d like to come.”
vi: "Tôi rất muốn đến dự."
tr: “Gelmek isterim“
es: Me gustaría ir.
vi_translation: "I really want to attend."
tr_translation: "I would like to come"
es_translation: I would like to go.

en: “Well, come then.”
vi: "Như vậy thì cứ đi."
tr: “Gelin öyleyse.
es: —Muy bien, entonces venga.
vi_translation: "In that case, just go."
tr_translation: "Then let's go.""
es_translation: —Very well, then come.

en: The hair in his nostrils quivered slightly, and as he shook his head his eyes filled with tears.
vi: Chùm lông trong mũi ông ta rung nhẹ, ông ta lắc đầu cặp mắt long lanh nước mắt.
tr: Burun deliklerinden fışkıran gür kıllar yine titrer gibi oldu; başını iki yana sallarken de gözlerine yaşlar doldu.
es: Los pelos de sus orificios nasales vibraron ligeramente y, mientras decía no con la cabeza, los ojos se le llenaron de lágrimas.
vi_translation: The tuft of hair in his nose quivered slightly, and he shook his head, his eyes glistening with tears.
tr_translation: The thick hairs sprouting from his nostrils seemed to tremble again; as he shook his head from side to side, his eyes filled with tears.
es_translation: The hairs in his nostrils vibrated slightly and, while shaking his head, his eyes filled with tears.

en: “I can’t do it—I can’t get mixed up in it,” he said.
vi: "Tôi không thể đi - Tôi không thể bị dính líu dây dưa vào." Ông ta nói.
tr: “Yapamam, bu işe karışamam.
es: —No puedo… No puedo mezclarme en eso —dijo.
vi_translation: "I can't go - I can't get involved." He said.
tr_translation: “I can't, I can't get involved in this.”
es_translation: —I can't… I can't get involved in that —he said.

en: “There’s nothing to get mixed up in. It’s all over now.”
vi: "Đâu có gì là dính líu. Mọi chuyện đã qua rồi."
tr: “Yapamam, bu işe karışamam. “Karışılacak bir mesele yok ki; her şey bitti artık.
es: —No hay nada en lo que mezclarse. Ya todo ha terminado.
vi_translation: "There is nothing involved. Everything is over."
tr_translation: “I can't, I can't get involved in this.” "There is no issue to interfere with; everything is over now."
es_translation: —There is nothing to get involved in. Everything is already over.

en: “When a man gets killed I never like to get mixed up in it in any way. I keep out. When I was a young man it was different—if a friend of mine died, no matter how, I stuck with them to the end. You may think that’s sentimental, but I mean it—to the bitter end.”
vi: "Khi một người bị giết, tôi không bao giờ muốn bị dính líu liên hệ. Tôi tránh xa. Khi còn trẻ thì tôi khác hơn, lúc đó nếu một bạn của tôi bị chết, dù bất cứ giá nào tôi cũng sẽ ở với họ cho đến cùng. Anh có thể cho như vậy là đa cảm, nhưng thật sự đúng là như vậy, tôi ở với họ cho tới phút đắng cay cuối cùng."
tr: “Ortada öldürülen bir adam varsa ben o işe katiyen bulaşmak istemem. Uzak dururum. Gençken böyle miydim? O zaman başkaydı tabi: bir arkadaşım öl­düğünde iki elim kanda olsa, son yolculuğuna uğurlamak için onun yanında olurdum. Beni fazla duygusal bulabilirsiniz ama sonunda ölüm de olsa yanında olurdum.
es: —Cuando matan a un hombre, no me gusta mezclarme. Me mantengo al margen. Cuando era joven, era distinto: si moría un amigo, y no importa cómo, seguía a su lado hasta el final. Quizá le parezca sentimental, pero hablo en serio: hasta el final, por amargo que fuera.
vi_translation: "When someone is killed, I never want to get involved. I stay away. When I was younger, I was different; back then, if a friend of mine died, no matter the cost, I would stay with them until the end. You might consider that sentimental, but it really was like that; I stayed with them until the bitter end."
tr_translation: “If there is a murdered man involved, I absolutely do not want to get involved in that matter. I stay away. Was I like this when I was young? It was different then of course: when a friend of mine died, even if my hands were covered in blood, I would be by his side to send him off on his final journey. You might find me overly emotional, but even if it ended in death, I would be there for him.”
es_translation: —When they kill a man, I don't like to get involved. I stay on the sidelines. When I was young, it was different: if a friend died, no matter how, I stayed by their side until the end. It may seem sentimental to you, but I'm serious: until the end, no matter how bitter it was.

en: I saw that for some reason of his own he was determined not to come, so I stood up.
vi: Tôi đã nhận ra vì một lý do cá nhân nào đó ông ta nhất định không đến dự đám táng, bởi vậy tôi đứng lên.
tr: Gelmemesinin kendince nedenleri olduğunu anlamıştım, ayrılmak için ayağa kalktım.
es: Vi que, por alguna razón particular, había decidido no asistir al funeral, así que me puse de pie.
vi_translation: I realized that for some personal reason, he definitely would not attend the funeral, so I stood up.
tr_translation: I understood that he had his own reasons for not coming, and I stood up to leave.
es_translation: I saw that, for some particular reason, he had decided not to attend the funeral, so I stood up.

en: “Are you a college man?” he inquired suddenly.
vi: "An h học đại học chưa?" Wolfsheim đột ngột hỏi.
tr: “Üniversiteye gittiniz mi?” diye sordu, damdan düşercesine.
es: —¿Ha ido usted a la universidad? —preguntó de improviso.
vi_translation: "An "Have you gone to college yet?" Wolfsheim suddenly asked.
tr_translation: “Did you go to university?” he asked, out of the blue.
es_translation: —Have you been to university? —he asked suddenly.

en: For a moment I thought he was going to suggest a “gonnegtion,” but he only nodded and shook my hand.
vi: Trong giây lát tôi đã tưởng ông ta muốn đề nghị một "mối làm ăn", thế nhưng ông ta chỉ gật đầu và bắt tay tôi.
tr: Bir an onun deyişiyle bir ‘ortaglıg” önerecek sandım fakat yanılmışım, sadece selam verip elimi sıkmakla yetindi.
es: Por un momento pensé que iba a proponerme una «coneggsión», pero se limitó a asentir y estrecharme la mano.
vi_translation: For a moment, I thought he wanted to propose a "business deal," but he just nodded and shook my hand.
tr_translation: For a moment, I thought he was going to propose a 'partnership' as he would say, but I was wrong; he just greeted me and shook my hand.
es_translation: For a moment, I thought he was going to propose a "coneggsion" to me, but he just nodded and shook my hand.

en: “Let us learn to show our friendship for a man when he is alive and not after he is dead,” he suggested. “After that my own rule is to let everything alone.”
vi: "Chúng ta hãy nên biểu lộ tình cảm tới một người khi anh ta còn sống chứ không phải sau khi anh ta đã chết," ông ta khuyên nhủ. "Ngoài đó ra, nguyên tắc của tôi là không nhúng vào chuyện gì."
tr: “Dostlarımız sağken onlara yakınlık göstermek önemlidir, öldükten sonra de­ğil!” diye ahkam kesti. “Ölümden sonra ben her şeyi öylece olduğu gibi bırakırım.
es: —Tenemos que aprender a demostrarle nuestra amistad a un hombre cuando está vivo y no después de muerto —sugirió—. Después mi regla es no mover las cosas.
vi_translation: "We should express our feelings to a person while he is still alive, not after he has died," he advised. "Other than that, my principle is not to get involved in anything."
tr_translation: “It is important to show affection to our friends while they are alive, not after they have died!” he pontificated. “After death, I leave everything just as it is.”
es_translation: —We have to learn to show our friendship to a man when he is alive and not after he is dead —he suggested—. Afterwards, my rule is not to move things.

en: When I left his office the sky had turned dark and I got back to West Egg in a drizzle. After changing my clothes I went next door and found Mr. Gatz walking up and down excitedly in the hall. His pride in his son and in his son’s possessions was continually increasing and now he had something to show me.
vi: Khi tôi rời khỏi văn phòng Wolfsheim thì bầu trời đã ngả tối và tôi quay trở lại West Egg trong cơn mưa phùn. Sau khi thay quần áo, tôi sang nhà bên và thấy cụ Gatz đang đi qua lại trong nhà một cách kích động. Niềm hãnh diện của cụ về con trai mình và những gì anh ta làm chủ không ngừng tăng lên. Bây giờ cụ có cái gì đó muốn khoe tôi.
tr: Oradan ayrıldığımda gökyüzünde toplanmış olan kara bulutları fark ettim; West Egg’e ulaşmamla da yağmur başladı. Üstümü değiştirip hemen komşumun evine gittim. Bay Gatz’ı sa­londa bir aşağı bir yukarı yürürken bulmuştum; çok heyecanlıydı. Oğlundan ve oğlunun malvarlığından gitgide daha fazla gurur duyuyordu.
es: Cuando salí del despacho el cielo se había oscurecido y lloviznaba al llegar a West Egg. Me cambié de ropa, me acerqué a la casa vecina y encontré a mister Gatz paseando por el vestíbulo, emocionado. El orgullo por su hijo y las posesiones de su hijo no había dejado de crecer y quería enseñarme algo.
vi_translation: When I left Wolfsheim's office, the sky had already darkened, and I returned to West Egg in the drizzle. After changing clothes, I went next door and found Mr. Gatz pacing back and forth in the house, agitated. His pride in his son and what he had accomplished kept growing. Now you have something to show me.
tr_translation: When I left there, I noticed the dark clouds gathered in the sky; as soon as I reached West Egg, it started to rain. I changed my clothes and immediately went to my neighbor's house. I found Mr. Gatz pacing up and down in the living room; he was very excited. He was becoming increasingly proud of his son and his son's wealth.
es_translation: When I left the office, the sky had darkened, and it was drizzling as I arrived at West Egg. I changed clothes, went over to the neighboring house, and found Mr. Gatz walking around the foyer, excited. The pride for his son and his son's possessions had not stopped growing, and he wanted to show me something.

en: “Jimmy sent me this picture.” He took out his wallet with trembling fingers. “Look there.”
vi: "Jimmy đã gửi cho tôi tấm hình này." Cụ lấy trong túi ra chiếc ví với những ngón tay run rẩy. "Anh xem đây."
tr: Bana bir şey göstermek istediğini söyledi. “Titrek elleriyle cüzdanından bir fotoğraf çıkardı, “Bunu bana Jimmy göndermişti” dedi, “Bak!
es: —Jimmy me mandó esta foto —sacó la billetera con dedos temblorosos—. Mire.
vi_translation: "Jimmy sent me this picture." The old man took a wallet out of his pocket with trembling fingers. "Look at this."
tr_translation: He said he wanted to show me something. “With trembling hands, he took out a photo from his wallet, "Jimmy had sent this to me," he said, "Look!"
es_translation: —Jimmy sent me this photo —he took out the wallet with trembling fingers—. Look.

en: It was a photograph of the house, cracked in the corners and dirty with many hands. He pointed out every detail to me eagerly. “Look there!” and then sought admiration from my eyes. He had shown it so often that I think it was more real to him now than the house itself.
vi: Đó là tấm hình của toà nhà của Gatby, góc hình đã bị rách và bẩn thỉu mang nhiều dấu tay. Cụ hăm hở chỉ cho tôi coi mọi chi tiết trong bức hình. "Nhìn đây này." Cụ vừa nói vừa nhìn vào mắt tôi tìm kiến sự ngưỡng mộ từ trong mắt tôi. Cụ đã khoe tấm hình quá nhiều lần đến nỗi tôi nghĩ đối với cụ tấm hình có lẽ còn có thật hơn là chính nó ở bên ngoài.
tr: Bu, içinde olduğumuz evin fotoğrafıydı. Kenarları aşınmış, elden ele dolaşmaktan üzeri kirlenmişti. “Şuna baksana?” diyerek hevesle bana tüm detayları gösteriyor, sonra bana bakıp gözlerimde bir hayranlık belirtisi arıyordu. Bunu o kadar çok kişiye göstermişti ki, onun için bu fotoğrafın evin kendisinden daha gerçek göründüğü izlenimine kapıldım.
es: Mire. Era una fotografía de la casa, rota por las esquinas y sucia de muchas manos. Me señaló cada detalle con fervor. «¡Mire esto!», y buscaba admiración en mis ojos. La había enseñado tantas veces que creo que para él era más real que la casa misma.
vi_translation: That is a picture of Gatsby's mansion, the corner of the picture is torn and dirty with many fingerprints. The old man eagerly pointed out every detail in the picture to me. "Look here." He said while looking into my eyes, searching for admiration in them. He had shown the picture so many times that I thought to him the picture might be more real than the actual mansion outside.
tr_translation: This was a photo of the house we were in. The edges were worn, and it was dirty from being passed from hand to hand. "Look at this?" he eagerly showed me all the details, then looked at me, searching for a sign of admiration in my eyes. He had shown it to so many people that I got the impression that this photo seemed more real to him than the house itself.
es_translation: It was a photograph of the house, torn at the corners and dirty from many hands. He pointed out every detail with fervor. «Look at this!», and he sought admiration in my eyes. He had shown it so many times that I believe it was more real to him than the house itself.

en: “Jimmy sent it to me. I think it’s a very pretty picture. It shows up well.”
vi: "Jimmy đã gửi tấm hình này cho tôi. Tôi nghĩ tấm hình này rất đẹp. Chụp lên rất có nét."
tr: “Bunu bana Jimmy yollamıştı. Çok güzel bir fotoğraf değil mi? Nasıl da net gösteriyor her şeyi.
es: —Me la mandó Jimmy. Creo que es una foto muy buena. Sale todo muy bien.
vi_translation: "Jimmy sent this picture to me." "I think this picture is very beautiful." "It is very sharp."
tr_translation: “Jimmy sent this to me. Isn't it a beautiful photo? It shows everything so clearly.’”
es_translation: —Jimmy sent it to me. I think it's a very good photo. Everything looks great in it.

en: “Very well. Had you seen him lately?”
vi: "Vâng rất có nét. Cụ lúc gần đây có gặp anh ta không?"
tr: “Gerçekten güzel. Yakınlarda hiç görüştünüz mü?
es: —Sí, muy bien. ¿Había visto a su hijo últimamente?
vi_translation: "Yes, very distinctive." "Have you seen him recently?"
tr_translation: “Really beautiful. Have you met recently?
es_translation: —Yes, very well. Had you seen your son lately?

en: “He come out to see me two years ago and bought me the house I live in now. Of course we was broke up when he run off from home, but I see now there was a reason for it. He knew he had a big future in front of him. And ever since he made a success he was very generous with me.”
vi: "Nó có về thăm tôi khoảng hai năm về trước và mua cho tôi căn nhà mà tôi đang ở bây giờ. Đương nhiên lúc nó bỏ nhà ra đi thì gia đình chúng tôi còn nghèo mạt, nhưng bây giờ nghĩ lại thì tôi hiểu rằng nó đi là có lý do. Con trai tôi đã thấy cả một tương lai tươi sáng trước mặt nó. Rồi sau đó, sau khi đã thành công, nó đã rất rộng rãi với tôi."
tr: “İki yıl önce beni ziyarete geldi ve bana şu an oturduğum evi aldı. Evi terk ettiğinde haliyle bozulmuştu aramız; fakat artık bir nedeni olduğunu görebiliyorum. Önünde parlak bir gelecek olduğunu o zamandan anlamıştı! Başarılı olduktan sonra da bana hep cömert davrandı.
es: —Fue a verme hace dos años y me compró la casa donde vivo ahora. Nos dejó destrozados cuando se escapó de casa, pero ahora veo que tenía motivos para hacerlo. Sabía que tenía un gran futuro por delante. Y en cuanto empezó a tener éxito fue muy generoso conmigo.
vi_translation: "It visited me about two years ago and bought me the house I am living in now. Of course, when it left home, our family was still very poor, but now looking back, I understand that it left for a reason. My son saw a bright future ahead of him. Then, after becoming successful, he was very generous with me."
tr_translation: “He visited me two years ago and bought me the house I am currently living in. When he left the house, our relationship was understandably strained; but now I can see that there was a reason for it. He had already realized back then that he had a bright future ahead of him! Even after becoming successful, he always treated me generously.”
es_translation: —He came to see me two years ago and bought me the house where I live now. He left us devastated when he ran away from home, but now I see he had reasons to do it. I knew he had a great future ahead of him. And as soon as he started to succeed, he was very generous with me.

en: He seemed reluctant to put away the picture, held it for another minute, lingeringly, before my eyes. Then he returned the wallet and pulled from his pocket a ragged old copy of a book called Hopalong Cassidy.
vi: Ông cụ miễn cưỡng không muốn cất đi tấm hình, ráng cầm nó thêm một phút nữa, cố nấn ná cầm trước mắt tôi. Sau đó cụ bỏ hình vào trong ví, lôi ra từ trong túi một quyển sổ cũ sờn và rách nát có tựa đề "HOPALONG CASSIDY".
tr: Fotoğrafı kaldırmaya isteksiz görünüyordu; bir müddet daha, oyalanırcasına onu gözümün önünde tuttu. Yeniden cüzdanına koyduktan sonra, bu defa cebinden Hopalong Cassidy adlı eski bir kitap çıkardı.
es: Parecía resistirse a guardar la foto y me dejó verla unos segundos más. Luego se guardó la billetera y se sacó del bolsillo un ejemplar muy viejo, mugriento y desencuadernado, de un libro llamado Hopalong Cassidy[25].
vi_translation: The old man reluctantly did not want to put away the picture, trying to hold it for one more minute, lingering to hold it in front of me. Then he put the picture into his wallet, pulling out from his pocket an old, worn, and tattered notebook titled "HOPALONG CASSIDY".
tr_translation: He seemed reluctant to put the photograph away; for a while longer, he held it in front of my eyes as if to stall. After putting it back in his wallet, this time he took out an old book called Hopalong Cassidy from his pocket.
es_translation: It seemed to resist putting the photo away and let me see it for a few more seconds. Then he put away the wallet and took out of his pocket a very old, grimy, and unbound copy of a book called Hopalong Cassidy[25].

en: “Look here, this is a book he had when he was a boy. It just shows you.”
vi: "Xem đây, quyển sách này là của nó khi nó còn bé, chứng tỏ nó là người như thế nào."
tr: “Şuna bir bak, bunu çocukken hiç elinden düşürmezdi. Daha o zamandan belliydi.
es: —Mire, este libro era suyo, de cuando era un chiquillo. Ahora verá.
vi_translation: "Look here, this book was his when he was little, proving what kind of person he is."
tr_translation: "Look at this, he never put it down when he was a child. It was clear even back then."
es_translation: —Look, this book was his, from when he was a little boy. Now you'll see.

en: He opened it at the back cover and turned it around for me to see. On the last flyleaf was printed the word schedule, and the date September 12, 1906. And underneath:
vi: Cụ mở quyển sách từ trang bìa cuối, sau đó xoay nó lại đưa cho tôi coi. Trong trang cuối của quyển sách có viết chữ "thời khóa biểu" và ngày ghi trên đó là tháng Chín, ngày 12 năm 1906. Dưới đó viết:
tr: Arka kapağını açtı ve görebilmem için kitabı bana çevirdi; boş olan son sayfada el yazısıyla PROGRAM yazıyordu. Üzerine 12 Eylül 1906 tarihi atılmıştı, altında ise bir çizelge vardı:
es: Lo abrió por el final y le dio la vuelta para que yo pudiera verlo. En la hoja de guarda habían escrito con letra de imprenta la palabra HORARIO y la fecha, 12 de septiembre de 1906. Y debajo:
vi_translation: The old man opened the book from the back cover, then turned it around and handed it to me to see. On the last page of the book, the words "schedule" were written, and the date recorded there was September 12, 1906. Below that, it was written:
tr_translation: He opened the back cover and turned the book towards me so I could see; on the last blank page, it was written in handwriting: PROGRAM. The date September 12, 1906, was inscribed above it, and below it was a schedule:
es_translation: He opened it from the end and turned it around so I could see it. On the flyleaf, they had written the word SCHEDULE in block letters and the date, September 12, 1906. And below:

en: Rise from bed 6:00 a.m.
tr: Yataktan kalkış 6. 00
es: Levantarse 6. 00
tr_translation: Getting out of bed 6. 00
es_translation: Wake up 6:00

en: Dumbell exercise and wall-scaling 6:15⁠–⁠6:30 “
vi: Tập tạ tay và leo tường...... 6. 15-6. 30 "
tr: Ağırlık çalışması ve duvara tırmanış idmanı 6. 15 - 6. 30
es: Gimnasia y pesas 6. 15-6. 30
vi_translation: Weightlifting and wall climbing...... 6. 15-6. 30 "
tr_translation: Weight training and the wall climbing training 6. 15 - 6. 30
es_translation: Gymnastics and weights 6. 15-6. 30

en: Study electricity, etc. 7:15⁠–⁠8:15 “
tr: Elektrik vb üzerine çalışma 7. 15 - 8. 15
es: Estudiar electricidad, etc 7. 15-8. 15
vi_translation: Study electricity, etc............ 7. 15-8. 15 "
tr_translation: Work on electricity, etc. 7. 15 - 8. 15
es_translation: Study electricity, etc 7. 15-8. 15

es: Trabajo 8. 30-16. 30

en: Baseball and sports 4:30⁠–⁠5:00 “
vi: Chơi bóng chày và thể thao............. 4. 30-5. 00 "
tr: 30 Beysbol ve spor 16. 30 - 17. 00
es: 30 Béisbol y deportes 16. 30-17. 00
vi_translation: Playing baseball and sports............. 4. 30-5. 00 "
tr_translation: Baseball and sports 16. 30 - 17. 00
es_translation: Baseball and sports 16. 30-17. 00

en: No wasting time at Shafters or [a name, indecipherable]
vi: NHỮNG QUYẾT TÂM CHUNG Không lãng phí thời gian ở nhà Shafters hay (ghi tên một người nào đó, tôi không đọc được).
tr: Shafters ya da (buradaki isim okunmuyordu) oyalanıp vakit harcamak yok
es: No perder el tiempo en Shafters o (nombre ilegible)
vi_translation: Do not waste time at Shafters' house or (insert someone's name, I couldn't read it).
tr_translation: * Shafters or (the name here was unreadable) no dawdling and wasting time
es_translation: Don't waste time at Shafters or (illegible name)

en: No more smokeing or chewing.
vi: Bỏ hút thuốc, bỏ nhai kẹo.
tr: Sigara içmek ve çiklet çiğnemek yok
es: Dejar de fumar y de masticar chicle
vi_translation: Quit smoking, quit chewing gum.
tr_translation: * No smoking and no chewing gum
es_translation: Quit smoking and chewing gum

en: Bath every other day
vi: Tắm gội hai ngày một lần.
tr: Gün aşırı banyo yapılacak
es: Baño un día sí y otro no
vi_translation: Bathe every other day.
tr_translation: * A bath will be taken every other day
es_translation: Bathing every other day

en: Read one improving book or magazine per week
vi: Hàng tuần đọc một quyển sách hay một tạp chí chuyên về nâng cao kiến thức.
tr: Her hafta iyi bir kitap ya da dergiyi okunacak
es: Leer una revista o un libro provechosos a la semana
vi_translation: Read one book or a specialized magazine to enhance knowledge every week.
tr_translation: * Every week, a good book or magazine will be read
es_translation: Read a useful magazine or book each week

en: Save $5.00 [crossed out] $3.00 per week
vi: Để dành $5. 00 (gạch bỏ) $3. 00 một tuần.
tr: Her hafta 5 bin dolar (bunun üstü çizilmişti) 3 bin dolar biriktilecek
es: Ahorrar 5 dólares 3 dólares a la semana
vi_translation: Save $5.00 (crossed out) $3.00 a week.
tr_translation: * Every week, 5 thousand dollars (this was crossed out) 3 thousand dollars will be saved
es_translation: Save 5 dollars 3 dollars a week

en: Be better to parents
vi: Cư xử tốt với cha mẹ.
tr: Anne ve babaya daha iyi davranılacak
es: Portarme mejor con mis padres
vi_translation: Behave well with parents.
tr_translation: * Parents will be treated better
es_translation: Behave better with my parents

en: “I came across this book by accident,” said the old man. “It just shows you, don’t it?”
vi: "Tôi tình cờ tìm được quyển sổ này. Nó thể hiện con tôi là người như thế nào." Ông cụ nói.
tr: “Bu kitabı şans eseri buldum” dedi ihtiyar, “durumu gayet iyi açıklıyor, değil mi? “Evet.
es: —Encontré este libro por casualidad —dijo el anciano—. ¿No es revelador?
vi_translation: "I happened to find this notebook. It shows what kind of person my child is." The old man said.
tr_translation: “I found this book by chance,” said the old man, “it explains the situation very well, doesn't it?” “Yes.
es_translation: —I found this book by chance —said the old man—. Isn't it revealing?

en: “It just shows you.”
vi: "Cụ nói đúng."
tr: Açıklıyor.
es: —Es revelador.
vi_translation: "You are right."
tr_translation: It explains.”
es_translation: —It's revealing.

en: “Jimmy was bound to get ahead. He always had some resolves like this or something. Do you notice what he’s got about improving his mind? He was always great for that. He told me I et like a hog once, and I beat him for it.”
vi: "Jimmy là người nhất định phải vươn lên. Nó lúc nào cũng có quyết tâm như vậy. Anh có để ý thấy những gì nó viết phải làm để phát triển đầu óc của mình không? Nó lúc nào cũng rất xuất sắc về chuyện đó. Có lần nó đã nói tôi ngu như heo, và tôi đã đánh nó vì dám nói như vậy."
tr: “Jımmy’nin hayatta ilerleyeceği kesindi. Her zaman buna benzer kararlar alırdı. Kendini geliştirmek için neler yapmış gördün mü? Hep böyle yapardı Bir kere­sinde bana bir domuz gibi yemek yediğimi söylemişti de ben de onu dövmüştüm.
es: —Jimmy estaba destinado a triunfar. Siempre se estaba proponiendo cosas por el estilo. ¿Se da cuenta de cómo se preocupaba de cultivar su inteligencia? En eso era ejemplar. Una vez me dijo que yo comía como un cerdo y le pegué.
vi_translation: "Jimmy is someone who definitely has to rise up. He always has that determination. Did you notice what he wrote about what needs to be done to develop his mind? He has always been excellent at that. Once he called me as dumb as a pig, and I hit him for daring to say that."
tr_translation: “It was certain that Jimmy would advance in life. He always made decisions like this. Did you see what he did to improve himself? He always did that. Once, he told me I ate like a pig, and I beat him up.”
es_translation: —Jimmy was destined to succeed. He was always setting goals like that. Do you realize how much he cared about cultivating his intelligence? In that, he was exemplary. Once he told me that I ate like a pig, and I hit him.

en: He was reluctant to close the book, reading each item aloud and then looking eagerly at me. I think he rather expected me to copy down the list for my own use.
vi: Ông cụ miễn cưỡng không muốn gấp quyển sổ lại, cứ đọc lớn tiếng mỗi phần, sau đó quay nhìn tôi một cách háo hức. Tôi nghĩ cụ mong cho tôi chép lại những gì trong sổ để đem về xử dụng cho mình.
tr: Kitabı kapatmaya pek istekli görünmüyor, her maddeyi yük­sek sesle okuduktan sonra yüzüme bakıyordu. Bu liste­yi kendim için kullanmak üzere ezberlememi istiyordu sanırım.
es: Se resistía a cerrar el libro, leía cada línea en voz alta y me miraba con ansiedad. Creo que incluso esperaba que copiara la lista para mi propio uso.
vi_translation: The old man reluctantly did not want to close the notebook, kept reading each part aloud, then turned to look at me eagerly. I think he hoped that I would copy what was in the notebook to use for myself.
tr_translation: He didn't seem very willing to close the book; after reading each item aloud, he would look at my face. I think he wanted me to memorize this list for my own use.
es_translation: He resisted closing the book, reading each line aloud and looking at me anxiously. I think he even expected me to copy the list for my own use.

en: A little before three the Lutheran minister arrived from Flushing, and I began to look involuntarily out the windows for other cars. So did Gatsby’s father. And as the time passed and the servants came in and stood waiting in the hall, his eyes began to blink anxiously, and he spoke of the rain in a worried, uncertain way. The minister glanced several times at his watch, so I took him aside and asked him to wait for half an hour. But it wasn’t any use. Nobody came.
vi: Khoảng gần ba giờ thì vị mục sư Tin Lành đến từ Flushing. Tôi bắt đầu ngóng nhìn ra cửa sổ một cách không tự chủ coi có xe nào khác tới không. Cha của Gatsby cũng làm như vậy. Thời gian cứ vậy mà trôi qua, khi những người hầu trong nhà tụ tập đứng dài trong nhà, lúc đó đôi mắt của ông cụ bắt đầu nhấp nháy tỏ vẻ nóng ruột, nhắc một cách lo lắng không rõ ràng nếu trời sẽ mưa. Vị mục sư liếc nhìn đồng hồ của mình nhiều lần, do đó tôi kéo vị mục sư sang một bên để xin ông đợi cho thêm nửa tiếng nữa. Nhưng cũng chẳng giúp ích được gì. Không một ai đến cả.
tr: Rushing’den çağrılan üç Protestan rahip henüz varmadan, pencerede durup başka otomobillerin gelmesini beklemekten kendimi alamadım. Gatsby’nin babası da aynı şeyi yapıyordu. Zaman ilerledi. Hizmetçiler salona doluşup beklemeye başlayınca Bay Gatz gözlerini kırpıştırmaya, kederli bir sesle ne diyeceğini pek de bilemeden yağmurdan söz etmeye başladı. Bir yandan da sık sık saatine bakıyordu. Onu bir kenara çekip yarım saat daha beklemesini istedim. Gerçi bir yararı olmadı. Kimse gelmemişti.
es: Poco antes de las tres el ministro luterano llegó de Flushing, y empecé a mirar involuntariamente por las ventanas para ver si aparecían más coches. El padre de Gatsby hacía lo mismo. Y, conforme pasaba el tiempo, cuando los criados esperaban ya en el vestíbulo, empezó a parpadear nerviosamente y a hablar de la lluvia con preocupación e incertidumbre. El ministro miró un par de veces su reloj, así que lo llevé aparte y le pedí que esperara media hora. Pero fue inútil. No vino nadie.
vi_translation: Around nearly three o'clock, the Protestant minister arrived from Flushing. I began to look out the window uncontrollably to see if any other cars were coming. Gatsby's father did the same. Time passed by like that, as the household servants gathered and stood in a line inside, at which point the old man's eyes started blinking, showing signs of impatience, anxiously remarking indistinctly if it would rain. The minister glanced at his watch many times, so I pulled him aside to ask him to wait for another half hour. But it didn't help at all. No one came.
tr_translation: Before the three Protestant ministers called from Rushing arrived, I couldn't help but stand at the window and wait for other cars to come. Gatsby's father was doing the same thing. Time passed. When the servants began to gather in the hall and wait, Mr. Gatz started blinking his eyes and talking about the rain in a sorrowful voice, not really knowing what to say. He was also frequently checking his watch. I pulled him aside and asked him to wait another half hour. However, it was of no use. No one had come.
es_translation: Shortly before three, the Lutheran minister arrived from Flushing, and I began to look out the windows involuntarily to see if more cars would appear. Gatsby's father did the same. And, as time passed, when the servants were already waiting in the vestibule, he began to blink nervously and talk about the rain with concern and uncertainty. The minister looked at his watch a couple of times, so I took him aside and asked him to wait half an hour. But it was useless. No one came.

en: About five o’clock our procession of three cars reached the cemetery and stopped in a thick drizzle beside the gate—first a motor hearse, horribly black and wet, then Mr. Gatz and the minister and me in the limousine, and a little later four or five servants and the postman from West Egg, in Gatsby’s station wagon, all wet to the skin. As we started through the gate into the cemetery I heard a car stop and then the sound of someone splashing after us over the soggy ground. I looked around. It was the man with owl-eyed glasses whom I had found marvelling over Gatsby’s books in the library one night three months before.
vi: Vào khoảng năm giờ, ba chiếc xe của chúng tôi đến nghĩa trang, ngừng bên cánh cổng dưới cơn mưa bụi mịt mờ. Đi trước là cỗ xe tang đen thui và đướt đẫm, sau đó đến cụ Gatz, vị linh mục và tôi trong chiếc xe limousine, cách xa hơn một tý là khoảng bốn hay năm người hầu và người đưa thư từ West Egg trong chiếc xe có khoang của Gatsby, người nào cũng ướt như chuột lột. Khi chúng tôi bắt đầu bước qua cánh cổng của nghĩa trang, tôi nghe có tiếng xe ngừng lại sau đó là tiếng chân của người nào đó bước bì bõm trên mặt đất sũng nước. Tôi nhìn chung quanh. Người mới đến đó là người đàn ông với đôi kiếng mắt cú vọ mà tôi đã có lần gặp đứng sững sờ trước những quyển sách của Gatsby trong một tối cách đây ba tháng.
tr: Akşamüstü beş sularında üç otomobilden oluşan tören alayımız mezarlığın kapısına ulaştı ve çiseleyen ince bir yağmurun altında durdu. En önde simsiyah ve ıslak cenaze aracı, arkasında Bay Gatz, rahip ve benim olduğum limuzin, biraz arkamızda ise iliklerine kadar ıs­lanmış olan beş altı hizmetli ile West Egg’li posta memurunun bulunduğu Gatsby’nin steyşın arabası vardı. Ana kapıdan geçip mezarlığa doğru yürürken bir arabanın durduğunu, sonra da birinin ardımızdan su birikintilerini sıçratarak geldiğini işittim. Dönüp baktığımda üç ay kadar önce, bir gece Gatsby’nin kü­tüphanesindeki kitapları hayranlıkla seyrederken gördüğüm baykuş gözlüklü adamı tanıdım.
es: A eso de las cinco nuestra procesión de tres coches llegó al cementerio y se detuvo a la entrada bajo una llovizna persistente: primero el coche fúnebre, horriblemente negro y mojado, luego mister Gatz, el ministro y yo en la limusina, y muy poco después, en la furgoneta de Gatsby, cuatro o cinco criados y el cartero de West Egg, todos empapados hasta los huesos. Cuando entrábamos en el cementerio oí que un coche se paraba y el sonido de alguien que chapoteaba en el suelo mojado detrás de nosotros. Me volví a mirar. Era el hombre con gafas como ojos de búho a quien descubrí una noche, hacía tres meses, maravillado ante los libros de la biblioteca de Gatsby.
vi_translation: Around five o'clock, our three cars arrived at the cemetery, stopping by the gate under a misty drizzle. Leading the way was the black and soaked hearse, followed by Mr. Gatz, the priest, and me in the limousine, a bit further behind were about four or five servants and mail carriers from West Egg in Gatsby's station wagon, all of them drenched like drowned rats. As we began to step through the cemetery gate, I heard a car stop and then the sound of someone's footsteps splashing on the waterlogged ground. I looked around. The newcomer was the man with owl-eyed glasses whom I had once seen standing in awe before Gatsby's books one evening three months ago.
tr_translation: At around five in the evening, our procession of three cars reached the cemetery gate and stopped under a light drizzle. In the front was the pitch-black and wet hearse, behind it was the limousine with Mr. Gatz, the priest, and me, and a little behind us was Gatsby's station wagon with five or six drenched servants and the West Egg postman. As we passed through the main gate and walked towards the cemetery, I heard a car stop and then someone splashing through puddles behind us. When I turned around, I recognized the man with owl-eyed glasses whom I had seen admiring the books in Gatsby's library about three months ago.
es_translation: Around five o'clock, our procession of three cars arrived at the cemetery and stopped at the entrance under a persistent drizzle: first the hearse, horribly black and wet, then Mr. Gatz, the minister, and I in the limousine, and very shortly after, in Gatsby's van, four or five servants and the West Egg postman, all soaked to the bone. As we were entering the cemetery, I heard a car stop and the sound of someone splashing in the wet ground behind us. I turned to look. It was the man with owl-like glasses whom I had discovered one night, three months ago, marveling at the books in Gatsby's library.

en: I’d never seen him since then. I don’t know how he knew about the funeral, or even his name. The rain poured down his thick glasses, and he took them off and wiped them to see the protecting canvas unrolled from Gatsby’s grave.
vi: Sau lần đó, tôi chưa hề gặp lại ông ta. Tôi không rõ tại sao ông ta lại biết tin chuyện đám tang, ngay cả tên ông ta tôi cũng không biết. Những giọt mưa nhiễu dài lên trên cặp mắt kiếng dầy cui của ông ta, ông ta gỡ kiếng xuống, chùi cho hết nước để có thể nhìn miếng vải phủ che mộ huyệt đang được mở ra.
tr: O geceden sonra onu görmemiştim. Cenazeyi nasıl ve nereden öğrendiğini, hatta onun adını dahi bilmiyordum. Yağmur suları gözlük camlarından akıyordu, Gatsby’nin mezarının üzerine serilmiş branda bezini görebilmek için gözlüklerini çıkartıp sildi.
es: No lo había visto desde entonces. No sé cómo se enteró del entierro, ni siquiera sé su nombre. La lluvia corría por sus gafas, muy gruesas, y él se las quitó y las secó para ver cómo levantaban la lona que protegía la tumba de Gatsby.
vi_translation: Since that time, I have not seen him again. I do not know why he knew about the funeral, I don't even know his name. Raindrops trickled down his thick glasses, he took them off and wiped them dry so he could see the cloth covering the grave being opened.
tr_translation: I hadn't seen him since that night. I didn't know how or where he learned about the funeral, nor did I even know his name. Rainwater was flowing down his glasses; he took them off and wiped them to see the tarpaulin spread over Gatsby's grave.
es_translation: I hadn't seen him since then. I don't know how he found out about the burial, I don't even know his name. The rain ran down his very thick glasses, and he took them off and dried them to see how they lifted the tarp that protected Gatsby's grave.

en: I tried to think about Gatsby then for a moment, but he was already too far away, and I could only remember, without resentment, that Daisy hadn’t sent a message or a flower. Dimly I heard someone murmur “Blessed are the dead that the rain falls on,” and then the owl-eyed man said “Amen to that,” in a brave voice.
vi: Tôi cố tập trung tư tưởng để tưởng nhớ về Gatsby trong giây lát, anh đã đi quá xa rồi. Tôi chỉ có thể nhớ lại, dù không một chút oán hận, rằng Daisy chưa hề gửi một lời nhắn hay một cành hoa đến. Tôi nghe có tiếng ai nói rì rầm không rõ ràng, "Phước lành ban cho người quá cố khi mưa rơi trên mộ họ." Sau đó người đàn ông mắt cú vọ nói "Amen" bằng một giọng kiên cường.
tr: Gatsby’yi düşünmeye çalışıyordum ancak o artık çok uzaklardaydı. Gücenmemiş olsam da aklım Daisy’nin ne bir haber, ne de bir çiçek göndermiş olmasına takılmıştı. Uzaktan birinin ‘Yağmur değen ölüler kutsanmıştır,’ diye mırıldandığını duydum; baykuş gözlüklü adam cesur bir sesle “Amin!” diye seslendi.
es: Intenté pensar en Gatsby un instante, pero ya estaba demasiado lejos, y lo único que pude recordar, sin resentimiento, fue que Daisy no había mandado ni un mensaje ni una sola flor. Apenas si oí vagamente un murmullo: «Bienaventurados los muertos sobre los que cae la lluvia». Y el hombre de los ojos de búho contestó con fuerza: «Amén».
vi_translation: I tried to concentrate my thoughts to remember Gatsby for a moment, he had gone too far already. I could only recall, without a hint of resentment, that Daisy had never sent a message or a flower. I heard someone murmuring indistinctly, "Blessings be upon the deceased when rain falls on their grave." Then the owl-eyed man said "Amen" in a resolute voice.
tr_translation: I was trying to think of Gatsby, but he was now far away. Though I wasn't offended, my mind was stuck on the fact that Daisy hadn't sent any news or even a flower. I heard someone in the distance murmur, 'Blessed are the dead who are touched by rain,' and the man with owl-eyed glasses responded boldly, "Amen!"
es_translation: I tried to think about Gatsby for a moment, but he was already too far away, and the only thing I could remember, without resentment, was that Daisy had not sent a message or a single flower. I barely heard a vague murmur: "Blessed are the dead upon whom the rain falls." And the man with owl eyes answered forcefully: "Amen."

en: We straggled down quickly through the rain to the cars. Owl-eyes spoke to me by the gate.
vi: Chúng tôi chật vật đi nhanh ra tới xe trong trời mưa. Ông Mắt Cú Vọ nói với tôi lúc tới cửa nghĩa trang.
tr: Kalabalıktan ayrılıp, sırılsıklam arabalara koşarken, baykuş gözlüklü yanıma geldi.
es: Volvimos deprisa a los coches, bajo la lluvia. Ojos de Búho habló conmigo en la puerta:
vi_translation: We struggled to quickly get to the car in the rain. Mr. Sharp-Eyed told me as we reached the cemetery gate.
tr_translation: As I left the crowd and ran towards the soaking wet cars, the owl-eyed one came up to me.
es_translation: We hurried back to the cars, under the rain. Owl Eyes spoke with me at the door:

en: “I couldn’t get to the house,” he remarked.
vi: "Tôi đến nhà không kịp." Ông ta giải thích.
tr: “Eve gelemedim” dedi.
es: —No he podido ir a la casa.
vi_translation: "I couldn't make it home in time." He explained.
tr_translation: "I couldn't come home," he said.
es_translation: —I couldn't go to the house.

en: “Neither could anybody else.”
vi: "Cũng chẳng có ai tới."
tr: “Aslına bakarsanız kimse gelemedi.
es: —No ha podido ir nadie.
vi_translation: "No one came either."
tr_translation: "In fact, no one could come."
es_translation: —No one has been able to go.

en: “Go on!” He started. “Why, my God! they used to go there by the hundreds.”
vi: "Vậy sao." Ông ta kinh ngạc "Trời ơi, tại sao, những người lui tới đó thường lên đến cả mấy trăm người." Ông ta gỡ mắt kiếng xuống để chùi một lần nữa từ trong ra ngoài.
tr: “Hadi canım!” dedi şaşkın şaşkın, “Ah Tanrım, yüzlercesi o evden çıkmazdı.
es: —¡No me diga! —estalló—. ¡Dios mío! Iban a cientos.
vi_translation: "Is that so." He was astonished. "Oh my, why, the people who frequent that place usually number in the hundreds."
tr_translation: “Come on!” he said in astonishment, “Oh my God, hundreds wouldn't come out of that house.”
es_translation: —Don't tell me! —he burst out—. My God! They were going hundreds.

en: He took off his glasses and wiped them again, outside and in.
vi: "Vậy sao." Ông ta kinh ngạc "Trời ơi, tại sao, những người lui tới đó thường lên đến cả mấy trăm người." Ông ta gỡ mắt kiếng xuống để chùi một lần nữa từ trong ra ngoài.
tr: ’’ Tekrar gözlüklerini çıkartıp sildi, bu defa hem içini, hem dışını.
es: Se quitó las gafas y volvió a limpiarlas, por dentro y por fuera.
vi_translation: He took off his glasses to clean them once more from the inside out.
tr_translation: He took off his glasses again and cleaned them, this time both inside and outside.
es_translation: He took off his glasses and cleaned them again, inside and out.

en: “The poor son-of-a-bitch,” he said.
vi: "Khốn khổ quá." Ông ta nói.
tr: “Zavallı hergele!” dedi.
es: —El pobre hijo de puta —dijo.
vi_translation: "So miserable." He said.
tr_translation: “Poor rascal!” he said.
es_translation: —The poor son of a bitch —he said.

en: One of my most vivid memories is of coming back West from prep school and later from college at Christmas time. Those who went farther than Chicago would gather in the old dim Union Station at six o’clock of a December evening, with a few Chicago friends, already caught up into their own holiday gaieties, to bid them a hasty goodbye. I remember the fur coats of the girls returning from Miss This-or-That’s and the chatter of frozen breath and the hands waving overhead as we caught sight of old acquaintances, and the matchings of invitations: “Are you going to the Ordways’? the Herseys’? the Schultzes’?” and the long green tickets clasped tight in our gloved hands. And last the murky yellow cars of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul railroad looking cheerful as Christmas itself on the tracks beside the gate.
vi: Một trong những ký ức sinh động sâu sắc nhất trong tôi là những lần khi tôi từ trường dự bị, và sau này khi từ trường đại học, về thăm nhà ở miền Tây vào mùa lễ giáng sinh. Những học trò nhà ở xa hơn thành phố Chicago sẽ tụ tập với nhau lúc sáu giờ chiều một ngày tháng Mười Hai dưới ánh đèn mờ của trạm ga xe lửa lâu đời Union Station. Còn có thêm vài người bạn ở Chicago, lúc đó đã sẵn sàng để tham dự vào những cuộc vui chơi tiệc tùng trong ngày lễ của mình, cũng có mặt ở sân ga tiễn đưa bạn vội vã. Tôi vẫn còn nhớ hình ảnh những chiếc áo choàng lông của những nữ sinh đang trở về nhà từ những ký túc xá nữ, nhớ những tiếng nói líu lo huyên thuyên từ những hơi thở đã biến thành hơi sương và những bàn tay giơ lên cao khỏi đầu vẫy chào khi thoáng gặp bóng dáng những người quen lúc trước. Rồi những lời mời mọc đáp lễ, "Bạn đi tới gia đình Ordways' à? Hay gia đình Herseys'? Hay gia đình Schultzes'?" Sau đó những chiếc vé tàu xanh dài được nắm chặt trong những bàn tay đang đeo găng của chúng tôi. Cuối cùng là hình ảnh những toa tàu lửa vàng màu của những tuyến đường Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul trông tươi vui như đêm giáng sinh, đang nằm trên những đường rầy cạnh bên cánh cổng sân ga.
tr: En canlı anılarımdan biri de, üniversitenin hazırlık sınıfındayken, sonra da fakülte yıllarında, Noel zamanlarında Batıya dönüşümdür. Chicago’dan da öteye gidecek olan bizler bir Aralık akşamında saat altıda eski ve karanlık Union İstasyonu’nda toplaşır, tatil havasına çoktan girmiş olan Chicago’lu dostlarımızla alelacele vedalaşırdık. Kürklerine sarınmış Miss falanca okulundan kızların ağızlarından buhar çıkarak çene çalmalarını, bir tanıdıkla rastlaşınca soğuktan donmuş ellerini hevesle sallayışlarını, “Ordway’lere mi gidiyorsun? Hersey’lere mi? Schuttz’lara mı?” diye oradan oraya seslenişlerini ve eldivenli ellerimizde sımsıkı tuttuğumuz o uzun, yeşil biletleri hiç unutmam. Chicago, Milwaukee ve St. Paul hattının kirli sarı renkli vagonları istasyona girdiğinde ise, Noel şenlikleri başlamışçasına neşelenirdik.
es: Uno de mis recuerdos más vivos es la vuelta al Oeste desde el colegio y, luego, desde la universidad en navidades. Los que seguían viaje más allá de Chicago se reunían en la vieja Union Station a la seis de una tarde de diciembre con algunos amigos de Chicago que, sumergidos ya en la alegría de las fiestas, acudían a despedirlos. Recuerdo los abrigos de piel de las chicas que volvían del colegio de miss Tal o miss Cual, y las charlas entre el vaho helado de la respiración, y las manos que se levantaban a saludar cuando veíamos a viejos amigos, y cómo comparábamos nuestras listas de invitaciones, «¿Vas a la fiesta de los Ordway, de los Hersey, de los Schultz?»[26]. Y los billetes del tren, alargados y verdes, bien apretados en las manos enguantadas. Y, por fin, en la vía, cerca de la entrada, los lóbregos vagones de la línea Chicago, Milwaukee y Saint Paul, que nos parecían alegres como las mismas navidades.
vi_translation: One of the most vivid and profound memories in me is the times when I returned home in the West for Christmas holidays from preparatory school, and later from university. Students whose homes were farther than the city of Chicago would gather together at six o'clock in the evening on a December day under the dim lights of the old Union Station train station. There were also a few friends from Chicago, who were ready to join in their own holiday festivities, present at the platform to bid a hasty farewell to their friends. I still remember the image of fur coats worn by female students returning home from the women's dormitories, the chattering voices from breaths that had turned into mist, and the hands raised high above their heads waving as they caught sight of familiar faces from before. Then the invitations to respond, "Are you going to the Ordways' family? Or the Herseys' family? Or the Schultzes' family?" After that, the long green train tickets were tightly held in our gloved hands. Finally, the image of the yellow train cars of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul lines, looking as cheerful as Christmas Eve, lying on the tracks next to the platform gate.
tr_translation: One of my most vivid memories is my return to the West during Christmas time, first when I was in the preparatory class of the university, and later during my faculty years. Those of us who were going beyond Chicago would gather at six o'clock on a December evening at the old and dark Union Station, hurriedly bidding farewell to our Chicagoan friends who had already embraced the holiday spirit. I will never forget the girls from Miss so-and-so’s school, wrapped in their furs, chatting away with steam coming from their mouths, eagerly waving their frostbitten hands when they ran into an acquaintance, calling out from one place to another, “Are you going to the Ordways? To the Herseys? To the Schuttzes?” and those long, green tickets we held tightly in our gloved hands. When the dirty yellow carriages of the Chicago, Milwaukee, and St. Paul line pulled into the station, we would cheer up as if the Christmas festivities had begun.
es_translation: One of my most vivid memories is the return to the West from school and, later, from university during Christmas. Those who continued their journey beyond Chicago gathered at the old Union Station at six on a December evening with some friends from Chicago who, already immersed in the holiday cheer, came to see them off. I remember the fur coats of the girls returning from Miss So-and-So's school, and the conversations amidst the frosty breath, and the hands raised in greeting when we saw old friends, and how we compared our invitation lists, "Are you going to the Ordways', the Herseys', the Schultzes' party?" And the train tickets, long and green, tightly held in gloved hands. And, finally, on the track, near the entrance, the gloomy carriages of the Chicago, Milwaukee, and Saint Paul line, which seemed as cheerful to us as Christmas itself.

en: When we pulled out into the winter night and the real snow, our snow, began to stretch out beside us and twinkle against the windows, and the dim lights of small Wisconsin stations moved by, a sharp wild brace came suddenly into the air. We drew in deep breaths of it as we walked back from dinner through the cold vestibules, unutterably aware of our identity with this country for one strange hour, before we melted indistinguishably into it again.
vi: Khi chuyến tàu của chúng tôi lao vào trong đêm đông thì tuyết trắng, phải rồi chính là những dải tuyết thật của quê chúng tôi, bắt đầu trải dài ở hai bên đường, phản chiếu lấp lánh qua những ô cửa sổ của con tàu. Những ánh đèn leo lét của những nhà ga nhỏ bé ở Wisconsin lướt qua nhanh và một làn không khí đầy kích thích cuồng nhiệt đột nhiên ngập tràn trong không gian. Chúng tôi hít sâu vào lòng ngực làn không khí đó khi bước về chỗ ngồi của mình từ bữa ăn chiều ngang qua những hành lang lạnh giá. Trong một giờ đồng hồ ngắn ngủi đầy lạ lùng này chúng tôi nhận thức ra được, một cách không sao diễn tả, những đặc điểm riêng biệt của mình so với quê hương này trước khi chúng tôi bị lẫn lộn vào trong nó một cách không sao còn phân biệt được nữa.
tr: Tren hareket edip kış gecelerinin içine daldığında sahici karlar, yani bizim karlarımız iki yanımızda uzanmaya ve camları lekelemeye başlar, Wisconsin istasyonlarının cılız ışıkları bir görünüp bir kaybolur olduğundaysa, ortalık bir anda keskin ve yabanıl bir havaya bürünürdü. Yemek vagonundan yerlerimize dönerken geçtiğimiz vagonlar arası soğuk geçitlerde işte bu havayı ciğerlerimize çeker, bu ülkeyle özdeşliğimizi, yeniden onun içinde eriyip kaybolmadan önce, hiç değilse bir saatlik bu tuhaf zaman diliminde derinden hissederdik.
es: Cuando nos adentrábamos en la noche de invierno y la verdadera nieve, nuestra nieve, empezaba a extenderse por todos lados y a titilar y estrellarse contra las ventanas del tren, y pasaban las luces mortecinas de las pequeñas estaciones de Wisconsin, el aire se endurecía de pronto, afilado y cortante. Lo aspirábamos profundamente cuando volvíamos de cenar a través de las plataformas heladas, inconcebiblemente conscientes durante una hora extraordinaria de nuestra identificación con el país, antes de unirnos y confundirnos de nuevo con él.
vi_translation: When our train plunged into the winter night, the white snow—yes, the very real snow of our homeland—began to stretch out on both sides of the tracks, reflecting and sparkling through the train's windows. The flickering lights of the small stations in Wisconsin quickly passed by, and a wave of thrilling excitement suddenly filled the air. We took a deep breath of that air as we walked back to our seats from dinner, passing through the cold corridors. In this brief and strange hour, we became aware, in an indescribable way, of our distinct characteristics compared to this homeland before we would be indistinguishably blended into it.
tr_translation: When the train moved and plunged into the winter nights, the real snow, that is, our snow, would start to stretch out on either side of us and stain the windows. As the feeble lights of the Wisconsin stations appeared and disappeared, the surroundings would suddenly take on a sharp and wild atmosphere. While returning to our seats from the dining car, in the cold passages between the cars we passed through, we would inhale this air into our lungs and deeply feel our connection with this country, at least for this strange hour-long period, before melting back into it and disappearing.
es_translation: When we ventured into the winter night and the real snow, our snow, began to spread everywhere and to twinkle and crash against the train windows, and the dim lights of the small Wisconsin stations passed by, the air suddenly hardened, sharp and cutting. We inhaled it deeply when we returned from dinner across the frozen platforms, inconceivably aware for an extraordinary hour of our identification with the country, before joining and blending with it once again.

en: That’s my Middle West—not the wheat or the prairies or the lost Swede towns, but the thrilling returning trains of my youth, and the street lamps and sleigh bells in the frosty dark and the shadows of holly wreaths thrown by lighted windows on the snow. I am part of that, a little solemn with the feel of those long winters, a little complacent from growing up in the Carraway house in a city where dwellings are still called through decades by a family’s name. I see now that this has been a story of the West, after all—Tom and Gatsby, Daisy and Jordan and I, were all Westerners, and perhaps we possessed some deficiency in common which made us subtly unadaptable to Eastern life.
vi: Đó là quê hương miền Trung Tây của tôi, không phải là những đồng lúa mì, hay những đồng cỏ, hay những thị trấn heo hút người Thụy Điển, mà là những chuyến tàu đầy cảm xúc đưa tôi quay trở về với tuổi thơ, về với những ngọn đèn đường, những chuông nhạc của xe trượt tuyết ngựa kéo trong đêm tối giá lạnh và những chiếc bóng của những vòng hoa treo cửa ngày lễ được chiếu rọi xuống mặt tuyết trắng từ những khung cửa sổ ngập tràn ánh đèn. Tôi là một thành phần của những thứ đó, hơi một chút trang nghiêm và đầy cảm xúc với những mùa đông dài giá lạnh này, hơi tự mãn vì đã mình sanh trưởng trong căn nhà của dòng họ Carraway, trong một thành phố nơi mà những căn nhà qua bao thập niên vẫn được gọi theo tên của gia đình. Bây giờ tôi thấy rằng cuối cùng câu chuyện vừa xẩy ra rốt cuộc vẫn là chuyện của miền Tây. Tom và Gatsby, Daisy và Jordan và tôi, tất cả đều là dân miền Tây, và có lẽ chúng tôi đã có cùng chung vài nhược điểm khiến chúng tôi cùng không thể thích nghi sống cuộc sống ở miền Đông.
tr: Benim Orta Batım buydu işte; buğday tarlaları, bozkırlar ve harap İsveç köyleri değil, gençli­ğimde heyecan içinde trenle eve dönüşlerim, ayaz karanlığın içindeki sokak lambaları, kızakların çın­gırak sesleri ve çobanpüsküllü Noel çelenklerinin pencerelerdeki ışıklarla kara vuran gölgeleri. Ben bunların bir parçasıyım, üzerimde o uzun kış gecele­rinin verdiği bir parça ağırlık, evlerin onlarca yıldır içinde yaşayanların aile isimleriyle anıldığı bir kentte Carraway’lerin evinde yetişmiş olmanın verdiği bir kanaatkarlık vardır. Tüm bu anlattıklarımın aslında Batının öyküsü olduğunu bugün anlıyorum: Tom ve Gatsby, Daisy, Jordan ve ben; hepimiz Batılıydık ve belki de, Doğu’nun yaşamına çok de ayak uydurmamızı gizliden gizliye engelleyen, ortak bir kusurumuz vardı.
es: Ése era mi Medio Oeste, no el trigo ni las praderas ni los perdidos pueblos de los suecos, sino los emocionantes trenes de mi juventud en los que regresaba, y las farolas de la calle y las campanillas de los trineos en la oscuridad escarchada y las sombras de las coronas de acebo que las ventanas iluminadas proyectaban sobre la nieve. Formo parte de ese mundo, un poco solemne por la sensación de aquellos largos inviernos, un poco orgulloso por haber crecido en la casa de los Carraway, en una ciudad en la que las casas todavía son conocidas durante décadas por el nombre de la familia propietaria. Ahora comprendo que, al fin y al cabo, esta historia ha sido una historia del Oeste: Tom y Gatsby, Daisy y Jordan y yo somos del Oeste, y quizá suframos en común alguna deficiencia que nos hace sutilmente inadaptables a la vida en el Este.
vi_translation: That is my Midwestern homeland, not the wheat fields, or the meadows, or the remote Swedish towns, but the emotionally charged train journeys that take me back to my childhood, to the streetlights, the sleigh bells of horse-drawn sleds in the cold dark night, and the shadows of holiday wreaths hanging on doors, illuminated on the white snow from the brightly lit windows. I am a part of those things, a bit solemn and full of emotions with these long cold winters, a bit complacent because I was born and raised in the house of the Carraway family, in a city where houses have been called by family names for decades. Now I see that in the end, the story that just happened was ultimately a story of the West. Tom and Gatsby, Daisy and Jordan, and I, we were all from the West, and perhaps we all shared some flaws that made us unable to adapt to life in the East.
tr_translation: This was my Midwest; not wheat fields, prairies, and dilapidated Swedish villages, but my youthful, excited train rides home, the street lamps in the frosty darkness, the jingling sounds of sleds, and the shadows cast by holly Christmas wreaths on the windows illuminated by lights. I am a part of these, with a bit of the weight given by those long winter nights upon me, and a sense of contentment from having grown up in the Carraway house in a town where homes are known by the family names of those who have lived in them for decades. Today, I understand that all these things I have described are actually the story of the West: Tom and Gatsby, Daisy, Jordan, and I; we were all Westerners, and perhaps we shared a common flaw that secretly prevented us from fully adapting to the life of the East.
es_translation: That was my Midwest, not the wheat or the prairies or the lost towns of the Swedes, but the thrilling trains of my youth on which I returned, and the street lamps and the sleigh bells in the frosty darkness and the shadows of the holly wreaths that the lit windows cast upon the snow.
